	<article id="post-281" class="post-281 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Giving to German</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<div id='gallery-1' class='gallery galleryid-281 gallery-columns-8 gallery-size-thumbnail'><figure class='gallery-item'>

			</div></figure><figure class='gallery-item'>
			<div class='gallery-icon portrait'>
				<a href='http://german.berkeley.edu/about/putzker-cabaret_6/'><img width="150" height="150" src="http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Putzker-Cabaret_6-150x150.jpeg" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" alt="" /></a>
			</div></figure><figure class='gallery-item'>
			<div class='gallery-icon portrait'>
				<a href='http://german.berkeley.edu/about/putzker-cabaret_7/'><img width="150" height="150" src="http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Putzker-Cabaret_7-150x150.jpeg" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" alt="" /></a>
			</div></figure>
		</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>To make a secure credit card gift to the Department of German, <a title="Give to Cal" href="https://givetocal.berkeley.edu/egiving/index.cfm?Org=German&amp;Fund=FN7208000" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">click here</a>!</strong></p>
<p>Your support allows the Department of German to assist graduate and undergraduate students. We gladly acknowledge your gift and will let you know how we spent it. You are welcome to specify how your contribution will be used. Some of our most urgent needs are study and travel stipends for our German majors; travel subsidies for our doctoral students who want to give papers at conferences; summer study grants for undergraduate and graduate students; and gifts to upgrade our departmental library and facilities.</p>
<p>If you would like to give a graduate student fellowship in your name or any other major award (for instance, a prize in your name for best essay or for excellence in teaching German language), please contact the Chair of the Department, <a title="Deniz Gokturk" href="/author/dgokturk/">Professor Deniz Göktürk</a> either by <a href="mailto:dgokturk@berkeley.edu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">email</a>, phone (510.642.7445), fax (510.642.3243), or letter (c/o Department of German, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720).</p>
<p>If you prefer to support the German Department with an unrestricted gift, please see <a href="https://givetocal.berkeley.edu/egiving/index.cfm?Org=German&amp;Fund=FN7208000" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Giving to the department</a>. If you would like to make a gift by check, please make it payable to "UC Berkeley Foundation, German Department" and mail it to UC Berkeley Foundation, Gift Processing, File #31932, PO Box 60000, San Francisco, CA 94160, to have it acknowledged for tax purposes.</p>
<p>If you want more information about other types of gifts, please consult <a title="Give to Cal" href="http://givetocal.berkeley.edu/give-your-way.cfm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Give to Cal</a>. For further questions, please call the Office of College Relations at (510) 643-1964.</p>
<p>Your support is greatly appreciated.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5052" class="post-5052 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Blackness in European Folklore &#8211; the Dutch Case: Black Pete, Dec 4</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/blackness-in-european-folklore-the-dutch-case-black-pete-dec-4/" title="5:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-12-04T17:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">December 4, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>This panel discusses the Low Countries' holiday blackface character Zwarte Piet (Black Pete) and the ongoing contestations it raises in the Netherlands from several perspectives. What can Black Pete tell about the way in which the Netherlands deals with its legacy of colonialism and slavery? Can the Black Pete controversies <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=83391&amp;date=2014-12-04" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/blackness-in-european-folklore-the-dutch-case-black-pete-dec-4/" title="5:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-12-04T17:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">December 4, 2014</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

				<nav class="nav-single">
					<h3 class="assistive-text">Post navigation</h3>

	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2572" class="post-2572 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Breadth Requirement</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>No German is required for the following courses. Please note that not all courses are offered each semester. For courses taught, please see the university schedule of classes.</p>
<p><strong>Arts and Literature</strong></p>
<p>German: 25, 39A, 39B, 39C, 39D, 39E, 39F, 39H, 39I, 39L, 100, 101, 102A, 105, C109, 110, 111, 112, C113, 120, 121, 122, 123, 130, 132, 140, 141, 142, 143, 145, 151, 152, 153, 154, 155, 156, C159, 161, 162, 165, 168, 175B, 175C, 176, 180, 180B, 181, 182, 183, 185, 186, 187</p>
<p>Dutch: 140, 150, 160, 161, 162, 163, 164, 165, 166, 177</p>
<p><strong>Historical Studies</strong></p>
<p>German: 39E, 120, 123, 141, 150, 153, 154, 157A, 157C, 157D, C157B, 160A, 160B, 160C, 160K, 164, 170, 176, 177</p>
<p>Dutch: 39A, C170, 173, 175, 177, C178</p>
<p><strong>International Studies</strong></p>
<p>German: 3, 4, 50, 100, 101, 102A, 102B, 102C, 102D, 103, 150, 160D, 188</p>
<p>Dutch: 110, 125, C170, 174</p>
<p><strong>Philosophy and Values</strong></p>
<p>German: C75, C113, 142, 143, 157A, 157C, 157D, C157B, C159, 162, 164, 176</p>
<p><strong>Social and Behavioral Sciences</strong></p>
<p>German: 25, 39F, 50, 102D, 103, 106, C109, 150, C159, 160A, 160B, 160C, 160D, 160K, 164, 171, 172, 173, 174, 177, 178, 180B</p>
<p>Dutch: 39A, C170, 173, 174, 175, C178, 179</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-3192" class="post-3192 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar, Body in Literature, Aug 29-Sept 26</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-body-in-literature-aug-29-sept-26/" title="2:02 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2008-08-01T14:02:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">August 1, 2008</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>This semester's compact seminar will be "The Body in Literature," taught by Max Kade Distinguished Visiting Professor Claudia Benthien.</p>
<p>This course only meets only the following five Fridays from 2-5 p.m. in 282 Dwinelle Hall: August 29, September 5, September 12, September 19, and September 26.</p>
<blockquote><p>Das Seminar zum Koerper in der Literaturì widmet sich einem Gegenstand, der in der kulturwissenschaftlich orientierten Germanistik seit den fruehen 1990er Jahren Popularitaet erlangt hat. Es fuehrt in zentrale Arbeitsbereiche und Themenfelder ein und erprobt ein Verfahren, dass Literatur und Wissensdiskurse verknoepft. Im historischen Durchlauf und anhand von unterschiedlichen literarischen Gattungen sollen zentrale "Epochen" einer Literaturgeschichte des Koerpers rekonstruiert und unter jeweils geeigneten kulturwissenschaftlichen Parametern wie Historische Anthropologie, Gender-Forschung, Performativitaet und Medialitaet diskutiert werden. Da sich in der deutschen Germanistik mit dem Fokus auf Anthropologie und Wissenschaftsgeschichte eine andere Richtung der "Koerperforschung" etabliert hat als in den USA, wo der Schwerpunkt mehr auf Cultural und Gender Studies lag, koennen anhand des Seminarthemas auch die unterschiedliche Wissenskulturen der German Studies verglichen werden.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>-Professor Benthien</p></blockquote>
<p>Taught in German.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-body-in-literature-aug-29-sept-26/" title="2:02 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2008-08-01T14:02:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">August 1, 2008</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-5050" class="post-5050 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar: German 204 taught by Professor Hinrich Seeba, Jan 30</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-german-204-taught-by-professor-hinrich-seeba-jan-30/" title="12:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-01-30T12:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">January 30, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>"Heinrich von Kleist: Dramatic Challenges to Truth" - Kleist's writings are an ideal guide to staging the literal meaning of language and to understanding the conceptual significance of verbal images. Identity formation, historical understanding, the lure of the abyss, the violence of stereotyping will be some of the topics to <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=84931&amp;date=2015-01-30" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-german-204-taught-by-professor-hinrich-seeba-jan-30/" title="12:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-01-30T12:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">January 30, 2015</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-3107" class="post-3107 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar on Faust, Sept 8-29</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-faust-sept-8-29/" title="12:26 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2006-09-01T12:26:09+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2006</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>This semester's German 204 compact seminar will be "Faust." Distinguished Professor Emeritus Wilhelm Vosskamp (University of Cologne) will teach the seminar for four weeks in September 2006.</p>
<p>The seminar will inaugurate the Compact Seminar in German Studies funded by the Max Kade Foundation New York.</p>
<p>One short paper is required. Note: This course only meets for one month, once a week, and on the following Fridays only: 9/15, 9/22, 9/29, 10/6, from 11 a.m.-1 p.m. in 282 Dwinelle Hall.</p>
<p><em>The seminar is listed in the schedule of courses as CC# 37588: German 204 section 001: 2 Units "Faust."</em></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-faust-sept-8-29/" title="12:26 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2006-09-01T12:26:09+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2006</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-3156" class="post-3156 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar on Kafka, Sept 7-Oct 5</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-kafka-sept-7-oct-5/" title="1:18 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2007-09-01T13:18:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2007</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Max Kade Distinguished Visiting Professor Joseph Vogl (Humboldt Unvisersität, Berlin) will be teaching German 204 in Fall 2007 under the title of "Kafka und die Mächte der Moderne."</p>
<blockquote><p>Einen 'Experten für Machtfragen' hat Elias Canetti Kafka einmal genannt, und zweifellos lassen sich Kafkas Texte als Spielarten einer politischen Literatur lesen. Diese Lektüre jedenfalls soll im Seminar an ausgewählten und exemplarischen Texten versucht werden. Neben einigen geläufigen Themen der Kafka-Forschung – etwa der Frage nach der Rolle von ‘Gesetz’ und Urteilsmacht, nach der Disziplinierung des Körpers – geht es dabei auch um die Erschließung einer immanenten Programmatik und Theorie von Kafkas Literatur. Auf der Basis gründlicher Textkenntnis, die für das Seminar vorausgesetzt wird, sollen zentrale Problemstellungen des Themas im Seminargespräch erarbeitet werden.</p>
<p>-Professor Vogl</p></blockquote>
<p>Class will meet on the following Fridays only: 9/7, 9/14, 9/21, 9/28, 10/5, from 2:00-5:00 p.m., in Dwinelle 282.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-kafka-sept-7-oct-5/" title="1:18 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2007-09-01T13:18:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2007</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-3244" class="post-3244 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar on Post-dramatic Theater</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-post-dramatic-theater/" title="11:11 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-02-01T11:11:34+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">February 1, 2011</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>This semester's compact seminar will be taught by visiting professor Hans-Thies Lehmann (Johann-Wolfgang-Goethe University, Frankfurt a.M.). The topic is "Post-Dramatic Theater."</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-post-dramatic-theater/" title="11:11 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-02-01T11:11:34+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">February 1, 2011</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-3252" class="post-3252 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Compact Seminar on Space &#038; Time</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-space-time/" title="11:23 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-09-01T11:23:24+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2011</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>This semester's compact seminar will be taught by Visiting Professor Gertrud Koch (FU Berlin). The topic is "Space and Time in Cinema”</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/compact-seminar-on-space-time/" title="11:23 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-09-01T11:23:24+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 1, 2011</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-12" class="post-12 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Courses</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<figure id="attachment_5886" style="width: 625px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682.jpeg"><img class="size-large wp-image-5886" src="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682-1024x682.jpeg" alt="Photo by Stephanie Peltner" width="625" height="416" srcset="http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682.jpeg 1024w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682-300x200.jpeg 300w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682-768x512.jpeg 768w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2975-2013-11-01-at-11-07-57-1024x682-960x639.jpeg 960w" sizes="(max-width: 625px) 100vw, 625px" /></a><figcaption class="wp-caption-text">Photo by Stephanie Peltner</figcaption></figure>
<p><strong>FAQ</strong></p>
<p><strong>Should I sign up during my Tele-BEARS appointment for all my language classes?</strong><br />
Yes, please, if at all possible. It would really help you to get the sections you want because some of them fill up fast. And you would help us determine where more sections are needed. So do yourself and us a favor and use your Tele-BEARS appointment!</p>
<p><strong>What happens if I missed Tele-BEARS and want to register at the last minute for a German course?</strong><br />
Just go to the section on the first day of classes and see if it's full. If it is, talk to the instructor about what options you might have. If you get into the class, remember that it's your responsibility to add the course through the registrar by the deadline.</p>
<p><strong>How do I find out where and when a language course is taught?</strong><br />
Well, you have three options: 1) you may check our <a title="Fall Courses" href="/fall-courses/">fall</a>, <a href="/spring-courses/">spring</a>, or <a href="/summer-courses/">summer</a> course pages, or go directly to the <a title="UCB Schedule of Classes" href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Online Schedule of Classes</a>; 2) you may stop by the department (5th floor Dwinelle/level E) and check the listings posted outside of the office at Dwinelle 5311; or 3) call the department office at (510) 643-2004. You can also check the printed University Schedule of Classes, but be aware that there are occasionally last-minute location changes which are not reflected in the printed schedule, so options 1 and 2 are your best bet.</p>
<p><strong>What if I can't find the class where I thought it was going to meet?</strong><br />
Sorry! Sometimes room assignments have to be changed at the last minute. You can get the latest info on the class location by checking the Online Schedule of Classes <a title="UCB Schedule of Classes" href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">website</a>, by stopping by the department (5th floor of Dwinelle Hall) and checking the listings posted outside of the office at Dwinelle 5311, or by calling the department office at (510) 643-2004.</p>
<p><strong>Do I really have to go to every class during the first week?</strong><br />
Ja, du musst. (Yes, you must.) No exceptions. Otherwise you risk losing your spot in the class. And guess what? We expect you to go to every class during the semester unless you have a really good excuse.</p>
<p><strong>Where do I go to practice my German?</strong><br />
You may consider taking one of the upper division courses offered in German. You could also enroll in our conversation class, German 40. For extracurricular fun, go to the weekly Stammtisch or Kaffeeklatsch, which meet every week during the semester. Check our <a title="Events" href="/events/">Events </a>listings for more information.</p>
<p><strong>If my German final overlaps with another exam, what do I do?</strong></p>
<p>Each semester we schedule an alternate final date for our German 1, 2, and 3 sections to accommodate students with exam conflicts. Please talk to your instructor for more information.</p>
<p><strong>Can I retake German 4 because I forgot most of it?</strong><br />
You may only repeat German 4 for credit if you received a grade of D+, D, D-, F, NP, or U the first time. If you want to refresh your German, consider taking German 45: Intensive Grammar Review (3 units) and/or German 40: Conversation (2 units).</p>
<p><strong>Can I study in Germany and still be done in four years?</strong><br />
Go study abroad for a semester or a year! You can study almost any subject in Germany and make normal progress toward your major. All your credits are transferable, and you save money overall thanks to scholarships and the low housing cost there. Currently it costs about $2,000 to 4,000 LESS for the twelve-month program in Göttingen than for the nine-month academic year at Berkeley (and that includes airfare)! There is now even an Education Abroad Program in Germany which requires no previous knowledge of German at all. Check our <a title="Study Abroad" href="/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a> section to explore your options.</p>
<p><strong>How can I use my BA in German?</strong><br />
If you don't want to attend graduate school, you can apply for jobs in international and global companies; you can work for a transatlantic organization, teach, do translations and much more. Have a look at the Career Center's web page about <a title="Career Center" href="https://career.berkeley.edu/International/International.stm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">International Careers</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Why does the German Department offer courses in English?</strong><br />
The German Department is more than a language department—we offer courses that provide a solid liberal arts major. Several courses on German philosophy, intellectual and cultural history, contemporary history, and film do not require knowledge of German. Although our major requires six upper-division courses taught in German, we also count four courses in English on German topics, offered either in our department or in affiliated departments. PLEASE CONSULT THE <a href="/author/nsamadi/">UNDERGRADUATE ADVISER</a> ABOUT COURSES THAT COUNT TOWARD YOUR MAJOR.</p>
<p><strong>How large are classes in the German Department?</strong><br />
Our language classes have between twelve and twenty students each; our literature classes have about ten to fifteen students each, and our "big" courses are limited to no more than fifty students per course. And with the exception of language classes, all of our courses are taught by regular Berkeley faculty.</p>
<figure id="attachment_5888" style="width: 625px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682.jpeg"><img class="size-large wp-image-5888" src="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682-1024x682.jpeg" alt="IMG_2834 - 2013-11-01 at 10-56-11" width="625" height="416" srcset="http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682.jpeg 1024w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682-300x200.jpeg 300w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682-768x512.jpeg 768w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/IMG_2834-2013-11-01-at-10-56-11-1024x682-960x639.jpeg 960w" sizes="(max-width: 625px) 100vw, 625px" /></a><figcaption class="wp-caption-text">Photo by Stephanie Peltner</figcaption></figure>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2572" class="post-2572 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Breadth Requirement</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>No German is required for the following courses. Please note that not all courses are offered each semester. For courses taught, please see the university schedule of classes.</p>
<p><strong>Arts and Literature</strong></p>
<p>German: 25, 39A, 39B, 39C, 39D, 39E, 39F, 39H, 39I, 39L, 100, 101, 102A, 105, C109, 110, 111, 112, C113, 120, 121, 122, 123, 130, 132, 140, 141, 142, 143, 145, 151, 152, 153, 154, 155, 156, C159, 161, 162, 165, 168, 175B, 175C, 176, 180, 180B, 181, 182, 183, 185, 186, 187</p>
<p>Dutch: 140, 150, 160, 161, 162, 163, 164, 165, 166, 177</p>
<p><strong>Historical Studies</strong></p>
<p>German: 39E, 120, 123, 141, 150, 153, 154, 157A, 157C, 157D, C157B, 160A, 160B, 160C, 160K, 164, 170, 176, 177</p>
<p>Dutch: 39A, C170, 173, 175, 177, C178</p>
<p><strong>International Studies</strong></p>
<p>German: 3, 4, 50, 100, 101, 102A, 102B, 102C, 102D, 103, 150, 160D, 188</p>
<p>Dutch: 110, 125, C170, 174</p>
<p><strong>Philosophy and Values</strong></p>
<p>German: C75, C113, 142, 143, 157A, 157C, 157D, C157B, C159, 162, 164, 176</p>
<p><strong>Social and Behavioral Sciences</strong></p>
<p>German: 25, 39F, 50, 102D, 103, 106, C109, 150, C159, 160A, 160B, 160C, 160D, 160K, 164, 171, 172, 173, 174, 177, 178, 180B</p>
<p>Dutch: 39A, C170, 173, 174, 175, C178, 179</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

<li id="menu-item-5786" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5786"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/courses/spring-courses/">Spring 2018</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5785" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5785"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/courses/summer-courses/">Summer Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-6139" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-6139"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/general-education-breadth-requirement-courses/">General  Education and Breadth Requirements</a></li>

						<div id="footer-widgets" class="widget-area three" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPSideBar">
											<div id="footer-widget-left">
							<aside id="googlemapswidget-3" class="widget google-maps-widget"><p><a data-gmw-id="googlemapswidget-3" class="gmw-thumbnail-map gmw-lightbox-enabled" href="#gmw-dialog-googlemapswidget-3" title="Click to open a larger map"><img width="150px" height="150px" alt="Click to open a larger map" title="Click to open a larger map" src="//maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?key=AIzaSyArcXkQ15FoOTS2Z7El2SJHDIlTMW7Rxxg&amp;scale=1&amp;format=png&amp;zoom=12&amp;size=150x150&amp;language=en&amp;maptype=roadmap&amp;markers=size%3Adefault%7Ccolor%3A0xffa500%7Clabel%3AA%7CDwinelle+Hall%2C+Berkeley%2C+CA+94704&amp;center=Dwinelle+Hall%2C+Berkeley%2C+CA+94704"></a></p></aside><aside id="text-2" class="widget widget_text">			<div class="textwidget"><a href="http://transit.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank"><img src="/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/translogo.png" alt="Transit"></a>

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-495" class="post-495 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Fall Courses</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Course Descriptions - Fall 2017</strong></p>
<p><strong>Language Courses</strong></p>
<p>Please note that all sections of German 1 through German 4 will still meet five hours per week, however at each level we are introducing sections that will meet three days per week, rather than five days per week.</p>
<p>German 1 (5) <strong>Elementary German I</strong>. Euba in charge.</p>
<p>Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet three or five times a week. All four foreign language skills (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) are addressed to help students acquire communicative competence in the German language while being sensitized to the links between language and culture. German 1 is for students with no prior knowledge of German.</p>
<p>German 2 (5) <strong>Elementary German II</strong>. Euba in charge.</p>
<p>Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet three or five times a week. In German 2, students will continue to develop communicative competence in the German language and expand their sensitivity toward the relationship between language and culture. While all language skills will be addressed, additional emphasis will be on the various styles of written and spoken German. Prerequisite: German 1 or equivalent.</p>
<p>German 1G/2G (S/U) <strong>Reading German for Graduates</strong>. Staff</p>
<p>Fall/Spring. Taken on S/U basis. Prepares graduate students from other disciplines to take their German reading exams. One year of German should be taken before 1G; 1G or consent of instructor is required for 2G. Students who will take 2G should enroll in it at the beginning of the semester; 2G will begin in approximately the eighth week of instruction. All students interested in the G courses should attend the first meeting of the semester.</p>
<p>German 3 (5) <strong>Intermediate German I</strong>. Topics in German Language and Cultural History. Euba in charge.</p>
<p>Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet three or five times a week. While continuing to expand students’ communicative competence in German, this content-driven course will provide insights into postwar German history and cultural trends. The primary focus will be on the development of literacy skills (critical reading and writing), vocabulary expansion, and a thorough review of structural concepts. Students will be guided toward expressing themselves on more abstract topics, such as language and power in society, multiculturalism, rebellion and protest, and social justice, and toward drawing connections between texts and contexts by using a variety of text genres (journalistic, historical, short story, poetry, drama, advertising, film).</p>
<p>German 4 (5) <strong>Intermediate German II</strong>. Topics in German Language and Culture. Euba in charge.</p>
<p>Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet three or five times a week. In this fourth-semester German language course, students work on strengthening their interpretative abilities as well as their written and oral forms of expression. While continuing the development of communicative competence and literacy skills, students will discuss a variety of texts and films and try to find innovative ways in which to engage with familiar presuppositions about who we are, about what determines our values and actions, and about the function and power of language.</p>
<p><strong>Reading and Composition Courses<br />
</strong>Readings and discussions in English. Fulfills the second half of the university’s Reading &amp; Composition Requirement (equivalent to English 1B, Comp. Lit. 1B, etc.).</p>
<p><strong>German R5A. </strong>Reading and Composition (4)</p>
<p>Section 1: Cho-Polizzi, J.<br />
"Untranslatables".  A globalized and digital world has rendered many of the most far-flung places and outlandish ideas little more than a mouse-click away, but even the best efforts of online translation technologies still fail in their attempts to provide satisfactory equivalents for culturally-specific concepts or words. Drawing from a survey of literature, philosophy, and academic writings, this R5 seminar will examine 10 such “untranslatable” German words through a critical cultural-historical lens, asking what a wider context might contribute to our own preconceptions and assumptions in projects of cultural-linguistic exchange.</p>
<p>Section 2: Salehi, K.<br />
"Politics and the German Imagination."  In every period in Germany’s eventful and turbulent past century, German literature, films, philosophy, and other cultural production have all reflected the hopes, fears, and deepest convictions of a society steeped in political contradictions. Drawing on German literature, theory, cinema, and digital media, this R5A course invites students to engage critically with the pressing social and political issues of Imperial, Weimar, Nazi, East, West, and reunified (and ever more multicultural) Germany, all through the lens of art and philosophy. Students will have a chance to develop familiarity with how Germans have imagined the relationship between art and politics, the nature of historical change, and the role of government in people’s lives. Students will come out of the course having cultivated the research, vocabulary, and argumentation skills necessary to write convincing academic papers.</p>
<p>Section 3: Shell, S.<br />
<span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;">The primary purpose of this <span class="il">course</span>, which fulfills the second component of the Reading and Composition Requirement, is to help students develop college-level skills in critical reading and academic writing. We will conduct close reading and analysis of texts, and the writing of clear and persuasive arguments. Subsequently, we will write a series of essays in which will be dedicated to general topics in grammar, rhetoric, and style. </span><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;">The theme of the <span class="il">course</span> aims to understand Germanic religion and mythology. We will use many major texts such as the<i> Poetic Edda</i>, the<i> Prose Edda</i>, the<i> Hêliand</i>, and <i>Völsunga Saga/Das Niebelungenlied</i>. In addition to this selection, we will also include fragments, e.g., laws against heathenry, place names, folklore surrounding the Germanic idea of a “soul”, that help to provide clues to the ancient Germanic religion(s) and myth(s). We will further explore these issues by researching the Christianization of the Germanic tribes and the degree of language contact within the migration period.  </span></p>
<p>Section 4: Fragomeni, M.<br />
In this course, we will consider the impact and influence of Rock &amp; Roll music during the Cold War, with a special emphasis on its effects in East Germany and the USSR. We will investigate how various Rock &amp; Roll genres challenged social conventions, as well as how they influenced the evolution of music itself. Concurrently, we will also cover the historical timeline in three units: Overview of the Cold War 1945 – 1991, Rock &amp; Roll of the 50’s and 60’s, and then of the 70’s and 80’s.</p>
<p>Section 5: Sacia, L.<br />
TBA</p>
<p><strong>Courses Taught in German:</strong></p>
<p>German 100 (3) <strong>Introduction to Reading Culture.</strong> Dewulf<br />
This course is intended to acquaint students with selected works from German cultural history and to familiarize them with various methods of interpretation and analysis. Required for all German majors. Fulfills the Letters &amp; Science requirement in Arts and Literature or International Studies. Taught in German. Students with native fluency in German are not eligible to enroll. Prerequisite: German 4.</p>
<p>German 101 (3) <strong>Advanced German Conversation, Composition, and Style. </strong>Euba<br />
Focusing on five central themes, this advanced-level language course will help students improve and expand on spoken and written language functions utilizing a variety of works from different genres in journalism, broadcasting, literature, fine arts, and cinema. The final goal is to enable students to participate in the academic discourse (written and spoken) to a linguistic and stylistic level appropriate for advanced students of German in upper division courses. Fulfills the Letters &amp; Science breadth requirement in Arts and Literature or International Studies. Taught in German. Students with native fluency in German are not eligible to enroll. Prerequisite: German 4.</p>
<p>German 102D (3) <strong>Advanced Language Practice: Popular Culture in Germany.</strong> Stirner<br />
TBA</p>
<p>German 103 (3) <strong>Introduction to German Linguistics. </strong>Shannon-CANCELLED!<br />
<strong>NOTE:</strong> Undergraduates<em> who still need or want to satisfy this course requirement in Fall 2017 can enroll in German 270 with Professor Rauch instead (please email Nadia Samadi with your student ID for manually enrollment).  German 270 will count as the German 103 requirement (Fall 2017 only).</em></p>
<p>German 105 (3) <strong>Middle High German. </strong>Largier<br />
The aim of the course is to help students develop proficiency in reading Middle High German texts. The course emphasizes translation, grammar, and close reading, though the cultural context of the literary documents and of the production of texts during the Middle Ages will be discussed as well. In addition to the courtly romance <i>Iwein</i> by Hartmann von Aue, students will read medieval poetry. The final list of readings and the way of proceeding will be determined in consultation with the class. The course is open to both undergraduate and graduate students.</p>
<p>German 151 (3) <strong>18th-21st Century Poetry</strong>. Kudszus<br />
Focusing on prime examples from 18th-21st century poetry in German, we will explore linguistic creativity, dream realities, identity formations, and questions regarding translation. Texts in German, lectures, discussions and assignments in German and/or English.</p>
<p><strong>Courses Taught in English:</strong></p>
<p>German 112/ Comp. Lit. 153 (3) <strong>Early Modern Literature.</strong> Largier<br />
"Martin Luther, the Bible, and the Reformation". According to the historical legend, Martin Luther posted 95 thesis about the reform of the Church on the doors of the castle church in Wittenberg, Germany, on October 31, 1517. These theses, published 500 years ago, were quickly reprinted, translated, and distributed throughout Germany and Europe. They are often seen as the starting point of the Reformation that not only changed the understanding of Christian teachings but also had a great influence on European culture and thought. In this course we read and discuss Luther's basic writings, the ways in which he teaches the reading of the Bible, and his influence on the history of modern thought and culture.  No knowledge of German required.</p>
<p>German 160A (4) <strong>A Century of Extremes.</strong> Richter<br />
This course will explore Germany’s political and cultural history from 1914 to the reunification of the two German states in 1990. This period was marked by the rise and fall of the first German democracy during the Weimar Republic, the First and the Second World War, the rise of extreme ideologies, the Cold War, and the fall of the Iron Curtain. Against the background of these developments we will focus on continuities and ruptures in German society during the Weimar Republic, National Socialism, the two Republics after 1949 (FRG and GDR), and the (unified) Federal Republic of Germany. By comparing the various dimensions and characteristics of Germany’s radical transformations this course introduces students to major political, social, and cultural changes, emphasizing questions of gender, class, religious identities and milieus; the impact of total war; and the roots of dictatorship and democracy. Course materials will include primary sources in translation and state-of-the-art scholarship on German history, self narratives, as well as contemporary literature, popular images, music and films.</p>
<p>German 186/Film 160 (4) <strong>Narrative and Performance: Imposter Tales.</strong> Gokturk<br />
In times of post-truth politics, this course focuses on imposter tales in literature and moving images, analyzing performances of social roles and national identities across multiple media and genres. Considering classic tales of “clothes make the man” from H. C. Andersen, F. Kafka, and T. Mann, cinematic productions such as <i>To Be or Not To Be</i>, <i>Imitation of Life</i>, and <i>Catch Me If You Can</i>, as well as acts of posing, passing, and exposing on TV, YouTube, and digital social media platforms, students learn to think critically about seductive qualities of narrative and performance with regard to rank and power, staging and acting, authenticity and artifice.<br />
<strong>NOTE:</strong> <em>This class includes "film screenings" on Wednesdays from 4pm-7pm in 142 Dwinelle Hall.</em></p>
<p><strong>Graduate Courses</strong></p>
<p>German 201E (4) <b> "Slow Reading: Literary Styles of Literary Modernism"</b><strong>.  </strong>Kaes<br />
This seminar will focus on concentrated readings of selected passages from German modernist literature, ranging from Heinrich von Kleist, Robert Walser, Rainer Maria Rilke, Carl Einstein, and Franz Kafka to Thomas Mann, Robert Musil, Ingeborg Bachmann and Thomas Bernhard, among others. Although the emphasis will be on short prose texts, we will also occasionally analyze lyrical or philosophical texts. The seminar’s project is to acquire and practice deep reading skills that draw equally on aesthetics, philology, rhetoric, stylistics, literary theory and media history. We will also examine theories of prose (Hegel, Agamben, et al.) and discuss examples by masters of critical reading (Benjamin, Adorno, Gadamer, de Man, Derrida, et al.). Reading knowledge of German is required.</p>
<p>204 (2) <strong>Compact Seminar.</strong> Gutjahr<br />
<strong>NOTE:</strong> <em>German 204 meets on the following 5 Fridays only: 09/1-09/29/2017.</em></p>
<p>Aufklärungstheater: Lessings Dramen und <em>Hamburgische Dramaturgie</em></p>
<p>Gotthold Ephraim Lessings Schauspiel <em>Nathan der Weise</em> (1779) gilt als <em>das</em> deutschsprachige Drama der Aufklärung schlechthin. Und dies nicht nur, weil es bis heute das am häufigsten auf der Bühne inszenierte Stück der Epoche ist, sondern auch, weil es mit seinen szenischen Dialogen auf unmittelbare Weise zu aufklärerischem Denken anleitet. Durch die Argumentationsweisen des Titelprotagonisten und seine veranschaulichende Erzählung der Ringparabel gewinnt ein Humanitätsgedanke Gestalt, der auf der Handlungsebene in einer religionsübergreifenden Familienkonstellation seinen sinnfälligen Ausdruck findet. Lessing suchte damit nur wenige Jahre, bevor Immanuel Kant in seiner Abhandlung <em>Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?</em> (1784) den »Ausgang des Menschen aus seiner selbstverschuldeten Unmündigkeit« zur epochalen Aufgabe erklärte, die Überwindung einer ›religiösen Unmündigkeit‹, die der unhinterfragten Übernahme dogmatischer Glaubensvorstellungen geschuldet ist, auf die Bühne zu bringen. Doch hat der an Erneuerung der Bühnenkunst interessierte Dramatiker bereits in seinen bürgerlichen Trauerspielen <em>Miss Sara Sampson</em> (1755) und <em>Emilia Galotti</em> (1772) wie auch in seinem Lustspiel <em>Minna von Barnhelm</em> (1767) Ansätze zu einem Aufklärungstheater entwickelt. Sein Ziel ist es, die Zuschauer auf bisher noch nie dagewesene Weise mit der dramatischen Handlung zu verbinden wie zugleich zur Kritikfähigkeit gegenüber dem Bühnengeschehen anzuleiten.</p>
<p>So kündigt Lessing zur Eröffnung des neugegründeten, von Bürgern finanzierten »Nationaltheaters« in Hamburg am 22. April 1767 seine <em>Hamburgische Dramaturgie</em> an mit den Worten: »Diese Dramaturgie soll ein kritisches Register von allen aufzuführenden Stücken halten, und jeden Schritt begleiten, den die Kunst, sowohl des Dichters, als des Schauspielers, hier thun wird.« Das Vorhaben des eigens für das Nationaltheater eingestellten ›Dramaturgen‹ ist es, den Zuschauern anhand von Aufführungsbesprechungen Formen des europäischen Theaters zu erklären und Kriterien der Beurteilung von Stücken und Inszenierungen an die Hand zu geben. Als Ziel seiner kritischen Analysen gibt er die Verbesserung der ästhetischen Geschmacksbildung und Kritikfähigkeit des Publikums an. Denn er war der festen Überzeugung, dass erst die Kenntnis vieler Stücke aus unterschiedlichen Theaterkulturen zu einer begründeten Kritik von Aufführungen befähigt.</p>
<p>In diesem Seminar werden wir Lessings Schauspiele, mit denen er als bedeutendster deutschsprachiger Dramatiker der Aufklärung in die Literaturgeschichte einging, vor dem Hintergrund seiner Ausführungen zur Funktion und Wirkungsästhetik des Dramas untersuchen. Dabei fragen wir, welche kosmopolitischen Vorstellungen Lessing mit seinem Vergleich von Theaterkulturen in der <em>Hamburgischen Dramaturgie</em> verbindet und ob sich daraus die Idee eines ›Welttheaters‹ ableiten lässt. Davon ausgehend analysieren wir seine bürgerlichen Trauerspiele <em>Miß Sara Sampson </em>und<em> Emilia Galotti</em>, das Lustspiel <em>Minna von Barnhelm</em> sowie das dramatische Gedicht<em>Nathan der Weise</em> im Hinblick auf die von Lessing selbst entwickelten Dramaturgien, die auf die Wirkung von Furcht und Mitleid wie auch auf Modelle aufgeklärter Rede ausgerichtet sind. Inwiefern heutige Inszenierungen von Lessings Stücken seine dramaturgischen Ansätze in postdramatische Formen übersetzen, erörtern wir ergänzend anhand von Videoaufzeichnungen neuer Inszenierungen an deutschsprachigen Theatern.</p>
<p>Von allen Seminarteilnehmern sind als Reclam-Bändchen für die eingehende gemeinsame Lektüre anzuschaffen: <em>Minna von Barnhelm </em>und <em>Nathan der Weise. </em>Textausschnitte aus <em>Miß Sara Sampson</em>,<em> Emilia Galotti</em> und der <em>Hamburgischen Dramaturgie</em> sowie ausgewählte Sekundärliteratur wird zum Herunterladen bereitgestellt.</p>
<p>German 207 (4) <strong>Methods. </strong>Feldman<br />
This graduate seminar offers an introduction to methods of reading and writing about German literature. We will examine a variety of theoretical approaches including psychoanalysis, memory studies, trauma theory, feminist theory, queer theory, New Historicism, translation, and deconstruction; and with respect to drama, poetry and the novel. Formal analysis will be emphasized. We will also consider the field of German Studies, how it is related to Germanistik, and recent controversies around the centrality of literature in our field. Professionalization exercises are a central part of this course, and we will refine skills necessary for graduate-level research and writing.</p>
<p>German 256 (4)<strong> Aesthetic Theory</strong>. <strong> </strong>Tang<br />
This research seminar is designed to help students gain an overview of the historical development and key concerns of aesthetic theory from its beginning in the late eighteenth century to the present day. The seminar will have three parts: 1. The emergence of philosophical aesthetics in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, with a focus on Kant and German idealism; 2, Aesthetics as a theory of modern society in the twentieth century, with readings ranging from Simmel and Adorno to Bourdieu and Rancière; 3. The rethinking of basic aesthetic categories under the contemporary scientific, technical, and social conditions. Aesthetic theory came into being at the height of humanism and revolves around the human subject. The seminar concludes by asking whether it is still possible and what form it could take under postman conditions.</p>
<p>German 263A (4) <strong>Translation.</strong> Kudszus<br />
In this seminar, we will think about and critically engage past and present practices and theories of translation. Following their particular interests in research &amp; writing, participants will choose a text or a constellation of texts for their individual semester projects. Additionally, we will jointly work on translating a variety of texts throughout the semester.</p>
<p>German 270 (4) <strong>History of the German Language.</strong> Rauch<br />
Designed for graduate and undergraduate students interested in the external and internal history of the German language from prehistoric times to the present and its interchange with closely and remotely related languages. Genetic language processes informing the German language across time are illustrated through the interface with literary documents from ancient cattle raids through runic, Gothic, Medieval German, and English texts, as well as excerpts from Luther’s era, modern, and contemporary German. No prerequisites.</p>
<p>German 294 (4) <b>Contrastive Grammars</b>.  Rauch<br />
Theory and methods used in various types of contrastive linguistic analysis. Study of pairs of contrastive sets in two time perspectives: Modern German with Modern English, and their immediate predecessors, Early New High German with Early Modern English. No prerequisites.</p>
<p><strong style="font-size: 1rem;">Pedagogy</strong></p>
<p>German 375A (3)<strong> Seminar in Foreign Language Pedagogy: Teaching College German I. </strong>Euba<br />
Focusing on the theory and practice of foreign language pedagogy, this course is designed to provide graduate students in German with knowledge and tools for their careers as teachers in the language classroom and beyond. While emphasizing critical reflection on pedagogical practices–-one’s own and that of others–-students will also be introduced to the field of Second Language Acquisition research and its relationship to pedagogy. This, along with the development of practices that promote continuing professional growth, should provide a basis for the ability to stay theoretically informed and to participate in the professional discourse of a rapidly developing field. Included in this course is a significant practical component addressing the day-to-day challenges of planning for and teaching the simultaneously offered elementary German language courses.</p>
<p><strong>Dutch</strong></p>
<p>Dutch 1 (5)<strong> Elementary Dutch</strong>. Van Der Hoeven<br />
Dutch language course for beginners. The focus of the course is on acquiring basic communicative competence in the language. That is, developing the ability to appropriately use the language (spoken as well as written) in authentic situations.</p>
<p>Dutch 110 (5) <strong>Advanced Dutch. </strong>Van Der Hoeven<br />
The focus of this course is on reinforcing and expanding the patterns and vocabulary acquired in Dutch 2. All major grammar will be reviewed. Written and spoken proficiency will be improved.</p>
<p>Dutch 171AC (4) <strong>From Amsterdam to New York. </strong>Dewulf<br />
A different look at the early colonial history of the United States from the perspective of the 17th century Dutch colony on Manhattan. No knowledge of Dutch required. SATISFIES AMERICAN CULTURES REQUIREMENT.</p>
<p><strong>Yiddish</strong></p>
<p>Yiddish 101 (5) <strong>Elementary Yiddish. </strong>Luzon<br />
Introduction to Yiddish language and literature. Attention to reading, writing, and speaking in the context of the historic Yiddish cultural environment.</p>
<p>Yiddish 103 (5) <strong>Yiddish Literature. </strong>Chaver<br />
Sholem Aleichem's Inner Child: Motl, the Cantor’s Son.  The last bittersweet masterpiece by the great Yiddish writer addresses challenges of change and modernity in the shtetl, in the fictional voice of a young boy who has just lost his father. With Motl, we experience traumas and joys, adventures and calamities, tradition and upheaval, culminating in the great shift out of the shtetl and into the New World. Sholem Aleichem’s rich style offers his unique take on the world of childhood in 19<sup>th</sup>-century Eastern European Jewish culture.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<article id="post-502" class="post-502 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Placement Guidelines</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>For Absolute Beginners</strong></p>
<p>If you have no prior exposure to German, you should start in German 1 (5 units). No matter what your motives for taking the language might be, our communicative approach will quickly bring you up to a reasonable level of proficiency in all four foreign language skills (reading, writing, speaking, and listening), while exposing you to the links between language and culture, and to the world of great thinkers and writers such as Nietzsche, Freud, and Kafka. We hope that your experience in this course will motivate you to continue our language sequence in German 2, 3, and 4. (All courses can also be taken in an intensive workshop format in the summer on campus or in Germany.)</p>
<p><strong>For Not-So-Absolute Beginners</strong></p>
<p>If you have had two years or less of high school German or simply want to brush up on prior basic knowledge, you should enroll in German 1E (3 units, meets three times a week), specifically designed to meet your background. The same material as in German 1 will be covered in a condensed way and at an accelerated speed, so you qualify for subsequent enrollment in German 2. Again, we hope that your experience in this course will motivate you to continue our language sequence in German 2, 3, and 4. (All courses can also be taken in the summer in an intensive workshop format.)</p>
<p><strong>For Students of German in High Schools (or otherwise continuing learners)</strong></p>
<p>Congratulations! Now you can take advantage of your prior achievements and continue with your German at a higher level--it is possible that you are only a few courses away from fulfilling the language requirement for a minor, major, or double major! Please start by placing yourself according to the guidelines below and attending the recommended course at the beginning of the semester.</p>
<p>You might also want to go to the university bookstore before classes start and look at the texts for the courses you're considering. This should give you some sense for the level. (In German 1, we cover through Chapter 6 of <em>Kontakte</em>; in German 2, we cover Chapters 7-12. In German 3, we cover chapters 1-6 of <em>Stationen, </em>and we finish chapters 7-12 in German 4).</p>
<p>Since we have a vested interest in making your foreign language learning experience a successful one, you can always change the level of course that you're attending as long as you do so by the beginning of the second week of classes.</p>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
<td valign="top" width="415"><strong>Background</strong></td>
<td valign="top" width="175"><strong>Recommended Placement</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#F2F2F2">
<td valign="top" width="415">Less than 1 year of high school German</td>
<td valign="top" width="175">German 1</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
<td valign="top" width="415">2 years or less of high school German</td>
<td valign="top" width="175">German 12</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#F2F2F2">
<td valign="top" width="415">3 years of high school German or</p>
<ul>
<li>passing grade in our German 1 or German 12 course or</li>
<li>passing grade in another college's second- or third-semester course (depending on total numbers of units awarded)</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="175">German 2</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
<td valign="top" width="415">4 years of high school German or</p>
<ul>
<li>AP score of 3 or</li>
<li>passing grade in our German 2 course or</li>
<li>passing grade in another college's third-semester course</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="175">German 3</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#F2F2F2">
<td valign="top" width="415">AP score of 4 or</p>
<ul>
<li>passing grade in our German 3 course or</li>
<li>passing grade in another college's fourth semester course</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="175">German 4</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>These are just starting points. If you've attended a class and think you might be in the wrong place, consult with your instructor and, if necessary, with the <a href="/author/euba/">Language Program Coordinator</a>. If you feel that your prior experience with the German language goes beyond the scenarios outlined above (e.g., heritage learner, study-abroad participation, etc.) and are planning to take an upper-division course, you must contact the Language Program Coordinator for a personal placement advising appointment.</p>
<p>To further advance your language skills, we also invite you to become a regular at the weekly Stammtisch or our weekly Kaffeeklatsch in the German Department library (Dwinelle 5337, on level E). You should also visit our website regularly and surf the net to exercise those "German muscles" in your brain. You can find anything from German news and pop music to interactive grammar exercises and e-mail partnerships.</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 15px;line-height: 28px"><br />
</span><strong>Fast Track Scenarios</strong></p>
<p>We pride ourselves on the quality and intensity of our dynamic and innovative German language program here at Berkeley. There are, of course, downsides that come with this approach to language learning--most notably time constraints and scheduling conflicts. We try to address these concerns as best we can and ask you to come to us for advice. Nikolaus Euba, the language program coordinator, is more than happy to meet with you.</p>
<p>Here are multiple scenarios for a fast track into the upper-division German language and literature courses (on the 100 level):</p>
<p><strong>Scenario 1 (Fall Beginners)</strong></p>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148"><strong>Semester 1 Fall</strong></td>
<td valign="top" width="148"><strong>Semester 2 Spring</strong></td>
<td valign="top" width="148"><strong>Summer</strong></td>
<td valign="top" width="148"><strong>Semester 3 Fall</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 1 or German 12</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 2</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 3 and 4</td>
<td width="148">Upper-division advanced course (German 100/101/103)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 2</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 3 or German 3 and 4 through EAP in Potsdam/Berlin</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 4</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">Upper-division advanced course (German 100/101/103)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">German 3</td>

<p><strong> Language Certification for German</strong></p>
<p>If you need proof of your German language skills (e.g., for scholarship applications, grants, or a graduate program), please contact the <a href="/author/euba/">Language Program Coordinator</a> to arrange for an evaluation.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
