	<article id="post-2776" class="post-2776 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Student Receives Berlin Program Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="2:23 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:23:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Eric Savoth received a dissertation fellowship from the Berlin Program for Advanced German and European Studies at the Freie Universität Berlin. His research will focus on the role of rationalization in literature and science around 1900 in Germany.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="2:23 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:23:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-2649" class="post-2649 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Student Receives Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-fellowship/" title="12:57 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2009-05-31T12:57:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2009</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Paul Dobryden was awarded a Center for German and European Studies/IES pre-dissertation fellowship.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-fellowship/" title="12:57 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2009-05-31T12:57:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2009</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-2798" class="post-2798 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Student Receives Leo Baeck Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-leo-baeck-fellowship/" title="2:34 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2013-05-31T14:34:25+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2013</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Yael Almog received a fellowship for 2013-14 from the Leo Baeck Fellowship<br style="color: #000000;font-style: normal" />program to work on her dissertation.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-leo-baeck-fellowship/" title="2:34 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2013-05-31T14:34:25+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2013</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-2770" class="post-2770 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Student Receives Mellon Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-mellon-fellowship/" title="2:21 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:21:51+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Kurt Beals, working on “Poetic Economies: Experimental Literature and Commercial Culture,” receives a Mellon/ACLS Dissertation Completion Fellowship.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-student-receives-mellon-fellowship/" title="2:21 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:21:51+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-2805" class="post-2805 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Students Publish New Book</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-students-publish-new-book/" title="2:38 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2013-05-31T14:38:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2013</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Ashwin Manthripragada, Emina Musanovic and Dagmar Theison published as editors the book, “The Threat and Allure of the Magical” (Cambridge Scholars, March 2013).</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-students-publish-new-book/" title="2:38 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2013-05-31T14:38:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2013</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-2694" class="post-2694 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Students Translate Plays for Berlin Theater</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-students-translate-plays-for-berlin-theater/" title="1:27 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2010-05-31T13:27:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2010</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Robin Ellis, Kristin Dickinson and Priscilla Layne translated the plays “Schwarze Jungfrauen” (by Feridun Zaimoglu), “Klassentreffen” and “Ferienlager” (by the akademie der autodidakten lab I) for the Ballhaus Naunynstraße in Berlin.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-students-translate-plays-for-berlin-theater/" title="1:27 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2010-05-31T13:27:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2010</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-5691" class="post-5691 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Symposium on German Medieval Studies</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-symposium-on-german-medieval-studies/" title="10:30 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2017-05-01T10:30:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 1, 2017</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The Graduate Symposium on German Medieval Studies will be convened this year at Stanford (May 4) and Berkeley (May 5).</p>
<p>Stanford - Wallenberg Hall, Room 433A</p>
<p>10:00 am. Welcome (Coffee and light refreshments)</p>
<p>10:15 am. Session 1<br />
Moderated by Kathrin Gollwitzer, Berkeley</p>
<p>Walker Horsfall, Toronto. “Mirrors and Mock Jousts: Metaphor as Ritual in Frauenlob”<br />
Mareike Reisch, Stanford. “sinne und vernunft:  Die bildliche Darstellung eines mittelalterlichen  Modells von Sinneswahrnehmung im  Konstanzer Haus zur Kunkel“<br />
Daniela Fuhrmann and Pia Selmayr, Zurich. “Narrated Orders - Orders of Narration”</p>
<p>12:30 pm. Lunch</p>
<p>1:30 pm. Session 2<br />
Moderated by Landon Reitz, Berkeley</p>
<p>Hans Pech, Harvard. “Vision and Imagination in Henry Suso´s Mysticism”<br />
Chris Hutchinson, Stanford. “Syphilis and its Cure: Ulrich von Hutten and Medi(c)al Communication”</p>
<p>3:00 pm. Break</p>
<p>3:45 pm. Session 3<br />
Barchas Room, Stanford Special Collections<br />
Moderated by Robert Forke, Stanford</p>
<p>Björn Buschbeck, Stanford. Manuscript Analysis<br />
Aleksandra Prica, Chapel Hill. Discussion of Primary Text: Basler Trojanerkrieg</p>
<p>---</p>
<p>5/5 Moses Hall 201</p>
<p>10:30 am. Session 5<br />
Moderated by Oriana Schällibaum, Zurich</p>
<p>Jon Martin, Princeton. “Are Marke and Isalde Married? An Examination of Legal Ritual in Eilhart's Tristrant”<br />
Thomas Müller, Zurich. “Performative Sanctification in Late Medieval Hagiography”</p>
<p>12:00 pm. Lunch</p>
<p>1:00 pm. Session 6<br />
Moderated by Patric Di Dio Di Marco, Stanford</p>
<p>Hannah Hunter-Parker, Princeton. “Lost Manuscripts: Classics from the German Homer to the Heldenbuch”<br />
Jake Wakelin, Toronto. “The Kaiserchronik in Perspective: German Vernacular Historiography in a Twelfth-Century Context”</p>
<p>2:30 pm. Break</p>
<p>3:00 pm. Session 7<br />
Moderated by Jenny Strakovsky, Stanford</p>
<p>Mae Lyons-Penner, Stanford. “The Global Medieval Sourcebook”<br />
Christopher Hench, Berkeley. “Phonological Soundscapes and the Lyrical ‘I’”</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-symposium-on-german-medieval-studies/" title="10:30 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2017-05-01T10:30:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 1, 2017</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

					<span class="nav-next"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/die-zweite-berkeley-cologne-summer-school-aesthetic-possibilities-literature-rhetoric-philosophy-ist-dem-thema-moglichkeitsdenken-einbildungskraft-phantasie-theorien-u/" rel="next">Die zweite Berkeley-Cologne Summer School “Aesthetic Possibilities: Literature, Rhetoric, Philosophy” ist dem Thema “Möglichkeitsdenken, Einbildungskraft, Phantasie: Theorien und Praktiken der Imagination” gewidmet. <span class="meta-nav">&raquo;</span></a></span>

						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Workshop: &quot;Begriffsgeschichte.&quot;, Mar 18</h1>

					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5226" class="post-5226 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Workshop on Freud and Moses, Oct 7</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-workshop-on-freud-and-moses-oct-7/" title="8:30 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-10-07T08:30:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">October 7, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>370 Dwinelle Hall, UC Berkeley <br />
Wednesday, October 7, 2015</p>
<p>A graduate workshop to complement the international conference Revisiting Freud and Moses: Heroism, History and Religion. That conference aims to explore Freud's place in current debates on secularism and post-secularism, featuring new research on the intersections of theology, Judaism and history in <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=92177&amp;date=2015-10-07" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/graduate-workshop-on-freud-and-moses-oct-7/" title="8:30 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-10-07T08:30:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">October 7, 2015</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

				<nav class="nav-single">
					<h3 class="assistive-text">Post navigation</h3>
					<span class="nav-previous"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/german-digital-humanities-oct-6/" rel="prev"><span class="meta-nav">&laquo;</span> German Digital Humanities, Oct 6</a></span>
					<span class="nav-next"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/revisiting-freud-and-moses-oct-7/" rel="next">Revisiting Freud and Moses, Oct 7 <span class="meta-nav">&raquo;</span></a></span>

	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2580" class="post-2580 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Our distinguished graduate program in German is both comprehensive and innovative, dedicated to German literature and linguistics, language and culture, but also to media, film, intellectual history, and theoretical approaches that reach beyond disciplinary boundaries.</p>
<p>We offer a broad range of research seminars that reflect the interests of our diverse faculty and most recent developments in the field. The topics of our <a href="/courses/">courses</a> range from Medieval literature to 21st century literature; from the literature of migration to studies in media and film; from Old Saxon and Gothic to modern German dialects; from bilingualism to the study of language and power; covering also relations among literature, law, space, philosophy, and religion.</p>
<p>Our <a title="Curriculum" href="/curriculum/">curriculum</a> offers a great range of flexibility. We are highly committed to working closely with our students to help them design the course of study that is most appropriate to their interests. Students can also qualify for one of many <a href="/programs/graduate/curriculum/#DesignatedEmphases">Designated Emphasis</a> programs.</p>
<p>In addition, we encourage our students to spend at least a year at a university in German-speaking Europe. Our department maintains an <a href="/international-networks/">extensive network</a> of international collaboration with the most innovative departments in the field at universities in German-speaking countries, notably with the Humboldt Universität and the Freie Universität in Berlin, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Universität Zürich, Universität Wien, and Universität Konstanz. We regularly host a considerable number of doctoral and postdoctoral students, as well as visiting faculty from these institutions, and they actively participate in our research seminars and colloquia.</p>
<p>Thus students develop their own networks with German colleagues early on during their careers. Nearly all of our students participate in exchanges with these universities and spend a year or two at host institutions in Germany, and most of them do so with the support of outside fellowships. Our students have been highly successful at securing such funding.</p>
<p>Students further support themselves in their studies by <a title="Teaching &amp; Pedagogy" href="/teaching-and-pedagogy/">teaching</a> lower-division German language courses. They can also apply to teach courses in Reading and Composition (offered in English on German topics). Our students prepare to teach with our language pedagogy program; they may also attend <a title="GSI Teaching &amp; Resource Center" href="https://gsi.berkeley.edu/conf_wkshop/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">seminars</a> about teaching Reading and Composition.</p>
<p>As part of their training, students are encouraged to participate in conferences and other professional activities, both on and off campus. The department offers several working groups, and students plan and put together the department’s annual interdisciplinary German Studies Conference. Based on their training in the department and their experience within our extensive international networks, our graduate students enter their careers with outstanding skills and a range of professional contacts in the US and in Germany. An excellent record of external grants and of <a href="/recent-graduates/">job placement</a> testifies to our students’ success.</p>
<p><strong>Contacts</strong></p>
<p><a href="/author/ctang/">Chenxi Tang</a> (Graduate Adviser in the Literature and Culture Specialization)<br />
<a href="/author/tshannon/">Thomas Shannon</a> (Graduate Adviser in the Germanic Linguistics Specialization).<br />
<a href="/author/germanga/">Andrea Rapport</a> (Graduate Adviser)</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-2782" class="post-2782 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Kudszus to Give Keynote in Finland, Teach Seminar in Latvia</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/kudszus-to-give-keynote-in-finland-teach-seminar-in-latvia/" title="2:25 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:25:59+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Winfried Kudszus will deliver the keynote lecture at the Metamind Symposium “Modelling of Time and Space”, which will take place at the International Semiotics Institute in Imatra, Finland, in June 2012.</p>
<p>In the summer of 2012, he will teach the compact graduate seminar “Critical Concepts of Text and Culture” at the Latvian Academy of Culture, Riga.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/kudszus-to-give-keynote-in-finland-teach-seminar-in-latvia/" title="2:25 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:25:59+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5082" class="post-5082 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Kyungtae Na wins the Berkeley Prize for Undergraduate Essays in German Studies</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/kyungtae-na-wins-the-berkeley-prize-for-undergraduate-essays-in-german-studies/" title="1:45 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-05-14T13:45:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 14, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<div>The departmental awards committee selected the essay "Subjectivity and Greece in Hölderlin's 'Hälfte des Lebens'" as the winner of this year's Berkeley Prize for Undergraduate Essays in German Studies.</div>
<div></div>
<p><div>We congratulate the author Kyungtae Na from New York University on this wonderful success! The winning essay will be considered for publication in our electronic journal <a href="http://transit.berkeley.edu/">TRANSIT</a>, and the winner will be awarded $500. The essay submissions provided us with a good cross-section of undergraduate research in the field.</div></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/kyungtae-na-wins-the-berkeley-prize-for-undergraduate-essays-in-german-studies/" title="1:45 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-05-14T13:45:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 14, 2015</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-4758" class="post-4758 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Lindsay Preseau receives Berlin Program Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/lindsay-preseau-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="12:11 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-04-01T12:11:07+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 1, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ldpres/">Lindsay Preseau</a> will be in Berlin next year through a fellowship with the <a href="http://www.fu-berlin.de/en/sites/bprogram/" target="_blank">Berlin Program for Advanced German and European Studies</a> working on her project "Kiezdeutsch and 'Kiezenglisch': Dialect Transfer in Multilingual Germany<i>".</i></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/uncategorized/" rel="category tag">Uncategorized</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/lindsay-preseau-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="12:11 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-04-01T12:11:07+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 1, 2015</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5399" class="post-5399 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Paul Dobryden accepts position as Assistant Professor at the University of Virginia, Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/paul-dobryden-accepts-position-as-assistant-professor-at-the-university-of-virginia-department-of-germanic-languages-and-literatures/" title="4:04 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2016-04-27T16:04:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 27, 2016</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Paul Dobryden has accepted a position as Assistant Professor at the University of Virginia, Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures. Congratulations, Paul!</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/uncategorized/" rel="category tag">Uncategorized</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/paul-dobryden-accepts-position-as-assistant-professor-at-the-university-of-virginia-department-of-germanic-languages-and-literatures/" title="4:04 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2016-04-27T16:04:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 27, 2016</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-2635" class="post-2635 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">PhD Grad Witt&#039;s Dissertation Published</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/phd-grad-witts-dissertation-published/" title="12:47 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2009-05-31T12:47:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2009</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Jason Witt (Berkeley PhD 2008, University of Manchester) published his dissertation “Evidentiality and Perception Verbs in English and German” (Bern: Peter Lang) 2009.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/phd-grad-witts-dissertation-published/" title="12:47 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2009-05-31T12:47:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2009</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2466" class="post-2466 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Programs</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<figure id="attachment_5871" style="width: 290px" class="wp-caption alignright"><a href="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re.jpg"><img class="wp-image-5871" src="http://dev-german.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re-200x300.jpg" alt="IMG_2661 - 2013-10-30 at 09-22-08" width="290" height="435" srcset="http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re-200x300.jpg 200w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re-768x1152.jpg 768w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re-683x1024.jpg 683w, http://german.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/IMG_08_re-960x1440.jpg 960w" sizes="(max-width: 290px) 100vw, 290px" /></a><figcaption class="wp-caption-text">Photo by Stephanie Peltner</figcaption></figure>
<p>The Department of German offers language and literature <a href="/courses/">classes</a> in German, <a href="http://dutch.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dutch</a>, and <a href="http://yiddish.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Yiddish</a>, as well as <a title="Breadth Requirement Courses" href="/breadth-requirement-courses/">breadth requirement courses</a> (taught in English) on German philosophy, linguistics, political culture, and cinema. The department's degree options include a <a href="/major/">major</a>, <a href="/minor/">minor</a>, <a href="/double-major/">double major</a>, or <a href="/graduate/">PhD</a> in German. Our renowned PhD program is affiliated with <a href="http://complit.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Comparative Literature</a>, <a href="http://filmmedia.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Film &amp; Media</a>, <a href="http://medieval.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Medieval Studies</a>, and <a href="http://criticaltheory.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Critical Theory</a>.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

<li id="menu-item-5779" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5779"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/courses/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-6130" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-6130"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/events/">Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-6119" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-6119"><a href="http://transit.berkeley.edu/">TRANSIT Journal</a></li>
</ul></div>		</nav><!-- #site-navigation -->

				<!-- Custom Header - Start -->
														<!-- Custom Header - End -->

	</header><!-- #masthead -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2580" class="post-2580 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Our distinguished graduate program in German is both comprehensive and innovative, dedicated to German literature and linguistics, language and culture, but also to media, film, intellectual history, and theoretical approaches that reach beyond disciplinary boundaries.</p>
<p>We offer a broad range of research seminars that reflect the interests of our diverse faculty and most recent developments in the field. The topics of our <a href="/courses/">courses</a> range from Medieval literature to 21st century literature; from the literature of migration to studies in media and film; from Old Saxon and Gothic to modern German dialects; from bilingualism to the study of language and power; covering also relations among literature, law, space, philosophy, and religion.</p>
<p>Our <a title="Curriculum" href="/curriculum/">curriculum</a> offers a great range of flexibility. We are highly committed to working closely with our students to help them design the course of study that is most appropriate to their interests. Students can also qualify for one of many <a href="/programs/graduate/curriculum/#DesignatedEmphases">Designated Emphasis</a> programs.</p>
<p>In addition, we encourage our students to spend at least a year at a university in German-speaking Europe. Our department maintains an <a href="/international-networks/">extensive network</a> of international collaboration with the most innovative departments in the field at universities in German-speaking countries, notably with the Humboldt Universität and the Freie Universität in Berlin, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Universität Zürich, Universität Wien, and Universität Konstanz. We regularly host a considerable number of doctoral and postdoctoral students, as well as visiting faculty from these institutions, and they actively participate in our research seminars and colloquia.</p>
<p>Thus students develop their own networks with German colleagues early on during their careers. Nearly all of our students participate in exchanges with these universities and spend a year or two at host institutions in Germany, and most of them do so with the support of outside fellowships. Our students have been highly successful at securing such funding.</p>
<p>Students further support themselves in their studies by <a title="Teaching &amp; Pedagogy" href="/teaching-and-pedagogy/">teaching</a> lower-division German language courses. They can also apply to teach courses in Reading and Composition (offered in English on German topics). Our students prepare to teach with our language pedagogy program; they may also attend <a title="GSI Teaching &amp; Resource Center" href="https://gsi.berkeley.edu/conf_wkshop/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">seminars</a> about teaching Reading and Composition.</p>
<p>As part of their training, students are encouraged to participate in conferences and other professional activities, both on and off campus. The department offers several working groups, and students plan and put together the department’s annual interdisciplinary German Studies Conference. Based on their training in the department and their experience within our extensive international networks, our graduate students enter their careers with outstanding skills and a range of professional contacts in the US and in Germany. An excellent record of external grants and of <a href="/recent-graduates/">job placement</a> testifies to our students’ success.</p>
<p><strong>Contacts</strong></p>
<p><a href="/author/ctang/">Chenxi Tang</a> (Graduate Adviser in the Literature and Culture Specialization)<br />
<a href="/author/tshannon/">Thomas Shannon</a> (Graduate Adviser in the Germanic Linguistics Specialization).<br />
<a href="/author/germanga/">Andrea Rapport</a> (Graduate Adviser)</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2586" class="post-2586 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Admissions</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The Department of German accepts applications for its graduate degree program* beginning in September for admission the following fall semester.<strong> </strong></p>
<p><em>Applications must be submitted online no later than December 15.</em></p>
<p><strong>Admissions Procedure and Criteria</strong></p>
<p>Criteria for the selection of applicants for graduate study* in German Literature and Culture or Germanic Linguistics include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>academic background (including grades) and interests</li>
<li>professional promise</li>
<li>evidence of intellectual initiative and commitment</li>
<li>potential for a successful teaching career at the university or college level</li>
<li>language proficiency in German</li>
</ul>
<p>The assessment of the applicant’s potential is based on the materials included in the <a title="Graduate Admissions" href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/index.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Application</a>, primarily on the statement of purpose (which should focus on potential contributions to the field), past record, and recommendations. A writing sample in English or in German that shows the applicant’s thought process and argument style is also required.</p>
<p>Please consult the <a href="/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Graduate-Application-Checklist1.pdf">Graduate Application Checklist</a> for a list of required components. Application questions may be sent to the <a href="/author/germanga/">graduate adviser</a>.</p>
<p>The departmental Graduate Admissions and Support Committee examines and evaluates within the first two weeks of each spring semester all completed applications that have been received by the department. The committee then makes its recommendations for admission to the Graduate Division in early February.</p>
<p>It also recommends awards of <a title="Teaching &amp; Pedagogy" href="/teaching-and-pedagogy/">Graduate Student Instructorships</a> (GSIs) and <a title="Awards &amp; Financial Aid" href="/awards-financial-aid/">fellowships</a> at this time. All applicants who have been recommended for admission and support will hear from the department by the end of February.</p>
<p><b>*</b> Please note that the department does not admit for the MA as a final degree, although the MA will be awarded to students pursuing work toward the PhD after fulfillment of the MA requirements. Applicants who hold an MA in German may apply directly to the PhD program.</p>
<p><strong>Reactivation of a Previous Application</strong></p>
<p>If you have applied within the last two years, you may reactivate your application by submitting form A of the current graduate application. The department recommends that you submit a new statement of purpose (Form F) and writing sample, an additional letter of recommendation, and transcripts of all coursework undertaken since you last applied.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2603" class="post-2603 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Awards &#038; Financial Aid</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The Department of German is committed to supporting all of its students. Our graduate students usually enter the program with a fellowship and further support themselves in their studies by teaching courses within the department. A fair number of fellowships are awarded to outstanding students not only at the incoming level, but also at continuing and dissertation levels. Students are encouraged to apply for extra-departmental funding throughout their graduate careers. The <a title="Graduate Division: Fellowships &amp; Awards" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/deadlines.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Division</a> provides an excellent listing of further funding opportunities.</p>
<p>All students applying for university fellowships or financial aid are required to complete the <a title="FAFSA" href="https://fafsa.ed.gov/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Free Application for Federal Student Aid</a> (FAFSA). Graduate students may apply for need-based loans and work study through the <a title="Graduate Financial Aid Office" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Financial Aid Office</a>. Under federal guidelines, all graduate students are considered independent. In order to receive aid, students must also be enrolled and be making satisfactory academic progress toward their degrees.</p>
<p><strong>Grants and Fellowships</strong></p>
<p>Each year the department is given a block grant from the Graduate Division to award fellowships to its students. Such grants may take the form of fee offset grants, tuition grants, stipends, or a combination of any or all. Students must complete the fellowship section in the <a title="Graduate Admissions -- Application" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/index.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Application</a> to be considered for financial aid upon admission.</p>
<p>Multi-year university-sponsored fellowships are awarded through an annual campus-wide competition administered by the <a title="Graduate Fellowship Office" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/deadlines.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Fellowship Office</a>. Departments select nominees for fellowships from the prospective applicant pool. Nominations are submitted for the following fellowships: Berkeley Fellowship, Chancellors Opportunity, Eugene Cota Robles, University Predoctoral Humanities, Regents Intern, GOP, and FLAS.</p>
<p>The GOP Fellowship is a need-based fellowship for under-represented individuals who have shown academic achievement despite social, economic challenges, or educational obstacles. The Graduate and Professional Unit (GPU) of the Financial Aid Office also administers three need-based programs for UC Berkeley students: the Federal Student Direct Loan Program, Federal Work Study Program, and the UC Parent Grant Program, which offers a need-based grant for Berkeley graduate students with dependent children.</p>
<p>Graduate students may apply for need-based loans and work study through the <a title="Graduate Financial Aid Office" href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Financial Aid Office</a>. All graduate students are considered independent under federal guidelines. In order to receive aid, students must also be enrolled and be making satisfactory academic progress toward their degrees.</p>
<p>For dissertation research abroad later in the student's career, the <a href="https://www.daad.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">German Academic Exchange Service</a> (DAAD) offers several <a href="/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Kurzbeschreibungen-regulärer-DAAD-Programme-Nordamerika.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">programs</a> and funding opportunities. Many of our students also apply for fellowships from the  <a href="http://www.cies.org/program/core-fulbright-us-scholar-program" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Fulbright Program</a>, <a href="http://www.acls.org/research/dcf.aspx?id=800" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Mellon/ACLS</a>, and the Freie Universität's <a href="http://www.fu-berlin.de/en/sites/bprogram/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Berlin Program for Advanced German and European Studies</a>. Further opportunities are listed on the Graduate Division <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/fellowships/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">website</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Teaching Positions</strong></p>
<p>Part of our graduate students’ training includes teacher training as a Graduate Student Instructor (GSI). Teaching also provides for a large portion of our students’ financial aid.</p>
<p>The guaranteed GSIship for entering students who hold a BA is normally limited to four years, while students entering with an MA are normally accorded only three years of teaching. A student who is on fellowship is allowed to teach only one semester per year while on fellowship.</p>
<p>GSI salaries depend on how long the student has been teaching. For normal periods of service, GSIs earn a pay increase after two years of teaching at the university, and again after three years of teaching. A higher appointment is normally reserved for students with four years of teaching experience who have advanced to doctoral candidacy, and who have a record of outstanding college teaching, a record of scholarly achievement (papers presented/published), have earned a minimum GPA of 3.4, and who will have a teaching assignment involving exceptional responsibility.</p>
<p>For further information, see <a title="Teaching &amp; Pedagogy" href="/programs/graduate/teaching-and-pedagogy/">Teaching and Pedagogy</a>. More information about teaching and research opportunities is also available through the <a title="Employment &amp; Teaching Opportunities" href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/financial/employ_teach_opps.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Graduate Division</a>.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2591" class="post-2591 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Curriculum</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Formal Requirements</strong></p>
<p>With the exception of the first semester of teaching and the semester of the qualifying examination (QE), students are expected to enroll in three courses per term at the upper-division (100-199) or graduate level (200-299), for a minimum of 12 units. A student may take a seminar on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory (S/U) basis if that student is enrolled in another research seminar for a grade. For seminars taken on an S/U basis, students are required to complete all assignments for the course except writing the final research paper.</p>
<p>For the MA, students should have completed at least 24 units by the end of the third semester; 12 of these units must be in graduate courses in the German Department. With the approval of the head graduate adviser, students may take a total of eight units of independent preparation for the QE (German 602) in the semester of this examination, or four units each in the semester before and the semester of the QE. Following advancement to candidacy and while writing their dissertations, students may enroll for 12 units of German 299 (Individual Study) per semester. There is no unit total required for the PhD.</p>
<p>The department’s formal requirements for graduation assume a student enters with a bachelor’s degree. Students entering the program with an MA from another institution must take the courses required of all students before the QE unless there is evidence of equivalent course work done elsewhere. Equivalency will be determined by the graduate adviser in consultation with the student, and a written statement to this effect will become a part of the student’s file. Such students will normally take the qualifying examination at the end of their third year or fifth semester. Yet the graduate adviser may grant an extension of one semester if the student's prior course work differs greatly from the program objectives at Berkeley.</p>
<p>For quick reference, we have provided a <a href="/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Graduate-Curriculum-Print-Version2.pdf">PDF of the formal requirements,</a> along with a series of possible coursework scenarios for completing the degree.</p>
<p><strong>Basic Requirements</strong> (12 units, 3 courses):</p>
<ul>
<li>Either Middle High German (Ger 105) , Old High German (Ger 276), or Gothic (Ger 273)</li>
<li>Methods (Ger 207)</li>
<li>History of the German Language (Ger 270)</li>
<li>Language Pedagogy requirement (6 units, 2 courses): Language Pedagogy I and II (Ger 350 and 351)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Comprehensiveness Requirements</strong> (20 units, 5 courses):</p>
<p>Five (5) graduate courses in the department, selected by the student in consultation with faculty advisers in view of the student’s desired specialization and in view of the historically comprehensive QE and the PhD.</p>
<p><strong>Further Specialization</strong> (minimum of 58 units):</p>
<ul>
<li>Electives chosen in the fields of specialization and outside interests (Joint PhD/Designated Emphases)</li>
<li>Exam preparation (maximum of eight units)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Language Requirement</strong></p>
<p>There are two options to fulfill the language requirement. Students are strongly encouraged to acquire a useful reading knowledge in two languages other than English and German (Option I). Many of our students choose French, Latin, Dutch, Italian, Russian, Japanese, or Turkish. If students choose to learn only one language other than English and German, they are required to demonstrate exceptional proficiency in this language (Option II). The languages should have value for the students’ research project and probable future career needs, and are selected in consultation with the adviser. The language requirement must be fulfilled prior to the QE.</p>
<p><em>Option I (two languages)</em></p>
<p>Students choose two languages relating to their research for a reading examination in both, or by examination in one and by completing a course in the other as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>If one of the two languages is Latin or Greek and the other language will be tested by examination, students may fulfill the requirement by completion of the two-course lower-division sequence in Latin or Greek with a grade of B or better during the regular semester or in an intensive summer workshop.</li>
<li>For any other approved language with a two-course lower-division sequence, completion of at least one upper-division course taught in that language with a grade of B or better will satisfy one language of the two-language requirement.</li>
<li>In languages with a four-course lower-division sequence, the student must complete the fourth course in the sequence and earn an average grade of B or better in all four courses in that sequence.</li>
</ul>
<p><em>Option II (one language)</em></p>
<p>Students must demonstrate an exceptionally thorough reading knowledge in a language related to their advanced research and pass an examination administered by an appropriate faculty member. They are also required to pass (with a grade of B or better) an upper-division or graduate course, approved by the adviser, with a majority of the course materials in the target language.</p>
<p><a name="DesignatedEmphases"></a><strong>Designated Emphases</strong></p>
<p>Graduate students may add a Designated Emphasis to their plans of study to gain a particular area of specialization. The Designated Emphasis is usually added before a student advances to candidacy.</p>
<ul>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="Dutch Studies" href="http://dutch.berkeley.edu/graduate/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dutch Studies</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="Critical Theory" href="http://criticaltheory.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Critical Theory</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a href="http://ies.berkeley.edu/graduates/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">European Studies</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="Renaissance &amp; Early Modern Studies" href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Renaissance and Early Modern Studies</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="Film &amp; Media Studies" href="http://fm.berkeley.edu/graduate/designated-emphasis/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Film &amp; Media Studies</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a href="http://folklore.berkeley.edu/programs/de.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Folklore</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="New Media" href="http://bcnm.berkeley.edu/index.php/designated-emphasis-program/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">New Media</a></li>
<li>Designated Emphasis in <a title="Women Gender and Sexuality" href="http://womensstudies.berkeley.edu/graduate/detail" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Women, Gender and Sexuality</a></li>
<li>Concurrent PhD in <a title="Joint PhD in Medieval Studies" href="http://medieval.berkeley.edu/programs/graduate" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Medieval Studies</a></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MA Examination</strong><br />
<b></b></p>
<p>The MA examination is a written exam based on a text not previously announced to the student, on methodological questions, or on linguistic problems from the student’s main field of interest. The examination is usually taken in the third or fourth semester.</p>
<p>By the sixth week of the semester in which the student takes the exam, the student will choose an examination committee consisting of three members, communicate to that committee an area of interest, and submit to the committee a list of works already read. The committee will choose an exam question, a text that is not on the reading list, or a linguistic problem from the area of interest and communicate it to the student two weeks before the examination. In response to the question, the student will write an essay in a three-hour time period.</p>
<p>Within a week after writing the examination, the committee will meet with the student to discuss the examination and the student’s progress in the program. At a meeting of the German Department faculty at the end of the fall semester, the faculty will decide whether the student will be invited to proceed to doctoral work in the program.</p>
<p><strong>PhD Qualifying Examination</strong></p>
<p>The PhD qualifying examination, or QE, consists of a written portfolio submitted to the student’s committee and a three-hour oral examination. The exam usually takes place in the student's seventh or eighth semester.</p>
<p>In the year before the QE, the student should decide on an exam committee of three faculty members from the department and one faculty member from outside the department. This committee must be approved by the head graduate adviser six months before the exam is to take place.</p>
<p>Once the committee has been approved, the student prepares a reading list for the exam. The reading list should show historical breadth while also highlighting texts within the student’s area of interest. Students generally choose a theme for their exams, to help make it easier for them to simultaneously showcase breadth and their research interests. Previous exam themes have included the apocalypse, problems with hermeneutics, the translator as a narrative character, and the genetic imaginary in literature. A <a href="https://www.zotero.org/groups/german_digital/items" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">digital database</a> of suggestions for the reading list is available via a Zotero group to help students get started with their own lists. The reading list must be approved by the QE committee chair a month after the committee has been approved by the graduate adviser.</p>
<p>In consultation with his or her committee, the student will then write a research proposal for the exam. This proposal usually follows the student’s exam topic as a “red thread” through German literary history. Sample prospectuses are available from the graduate assistant. The research proposal must be submitted to the committee by the first week of the semester in which the QE is to take place.</p>
<p>The student must also turn in two revised papers from seminars he or she has taken in the department (Option I) or write two three-hour exams (Option II). Most students choose Option I. These are to be turned in to the committee with the research proposal and a final draft of the reading list.</p>
<p>The QE is a three-hour exam. The committee will decide during the exam whether or not to pass the student. If the student passes the exam, he or she will advance to candidacy.</p>
<p><strong>Prospectus Conference</strong></p>
<p>By the end of the semester after the QE, the student will submit to his or her dissertation committee a prospectus and any other work completed on the dissertation. After examining these materials, the dissertation committee will meet with the student to discuss progress and to offer advice. If the student is not available for this conference (for example, because of a research year abroad), the committee will meet without the student and the dissertation adviser will communicate the committee’s advice to the student. Annually thereafter, it is required that at least two members of the committee confer with the student, in addition to regular meetings with the dissertation chair.</p>
<p><strong>Dissertation</strong></p>
<p>The final requirement of the PhD is completion of a dissertation. Students should meet with their dissertation chairs to decide on appropriate timelines for research, time abroad, and the completion of individual chapters. Students are not required to defend the dissertation once the dissertation committee has decided the dissertation is finished.</p>
<p>For further details and questions, please contact the Head Graduate Adviser, <a href="/author/ctang/">Chenxi Tang</a>, or the Graduate Program Adviser, <a href="/author/germanga/">Andrea Rapport</a>.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-400" class="post-400 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">International Networks</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The Department of German entertains a lively network of research connections with several universities abroad, offering graduate students the possibility to work with acclaimed faculty at other research institutions and to develop their own international networks early in their careers.</p>
<p><strong>Humboldt University, Berlin</strong></p>
<p>The Department of German is a founding member of the PhD-Net <a title="Das Wissen der Literatur Website" href="http://www2.hu-berlin.de/wissen-literatur/index.php" target="_blank">Das Wissen der Literatur</a> established at Humboldt Universität zu Berlin in 2008. The network includes the departments of German at Humboldt Universität zu Berlin, UC Berkeley, Harvard University, and Princeton University. It offers graduate students the possibility to study for one or two semesters at a partner institution and to participate in the shared thematic emphasis on the relationship between literature and forms of knowledge. The international collaboration offers students the possibility to work with renowned scholars at several research institutions and to engage in theoretical discussions about recent work in Europe and in the US.</p>
<p><strong>University of Konstanz</strong></p>
<p>The Department of German is a founding partner in the MA program <a title="MA Program Website" href="http://www.exc16.de/cms/europa-studiengang.html" target="_blank">Kulturelle Grundlagen Europas</a> at Universität Konstanz. The program offers students who specialize in questions of literature, migration, and globalization the possibility to pursue their studies and research projects with expert faculty at both universities and through student exchange.</p>
<p><strong>Ludwig-Maximilian University, Munich</strong></p>
<p>An agreement of cooperation between UC Berkeley and Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München offers graduate students and faculty at both universities a new platform for international cooperation and exchange.</p>
<p><strong>Cambridge University, UK</strong></p>
<p>The German Department at UC Berkeley currently is working on a cooperation with Cambridge University in the UK. Research areas in this cooperation include literature and film of the Weimar period and Medieval studies.</p>
<p><strong>Berkeley-Tübingen-Vienna-Harvard (BTWH) Working Group</strong></p>
<p>Graduate students in the Department of German are members of the <a title="BTWH Website" href="http://btwh.info" target="_blank">Berkeley-Tübingen-Wien-Harvard</a> working group, an international cooperation of graduate students supported by the Townsend Center at UC Berkeley. This working group focuses on specific topics in literary theory and history, and organizes an annual international conference.</p>
<p class="bodytext"><b>"Aesthetic Possibilities: Literature, Rhetoric, Philosophy" - Berkeley-Köln Summer School</b></p>
<p class="bodytext">The Berkeley-Köln Summer School, established by the Anneliese Maier prize, offers graduate students the opportunity for intensive discussions focussed on aesthetics, rhetoric, and literary criticism with an international team of professors from Philosophy, Cultural Studies, Literary Studies, and Media Studies. The goal is to work cooperatively on theoretical questions beyond disciplinary boundaries.</p>
<p class="bodytext">The five-day summer school will alternate between the <a class="external-link-new-window" title="Opens external link in new window" href="http://idsl1.phil-fak.uni-koeln.de/8858.html?&amp;L=0" target="_blank">Universität zu Köln</a> and <a class="external-link-new-window" title="Opens external link in new window" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">UC Berkeley</a>. In the mornings there will be a seminar directed by one of the experts, in the afternoons there will be project presentations by participants. The discussion will be based on pre-distributed texts. The summer school will be conducted in both English and German.</p>
<p class="bodytext">
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-425" class="post-425 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Past Dissertations</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<h1>Dissertations Filed in German Literature and Germanic Linguistics since 1908</h1>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>2015-2016</p>
<p><strong>Born, Erik</strong><br />
Sparks to Signals: Literature, Science and Wireless Technology, 1800-1930</p>
<p><strong>Johnson, Courtney</strong><br />
Inside in the City: Domestic Space in the Literature and Film of Weimar Berlin</p>
<p><strong>Savoth, Eric</strong><br />
Responding to Pain: Emotion, Medicine, and Culture between German Naturalism and Modernism</p>
<p>2014-2015</p>
<p><strong>Almog, Yael</strong><br />
Hebrew Reminiscences: Global Religion, Politics and Aesthetics in the Rise of Hermeneutic Thinking</p>
<p><strong>Dickinson, Kristin </strong>(filed in Comparative Literature with Deniz Göktürk as Adviser)<br />
Translation and the Experience of Modernity: A History of German Turkish Connectivity</p>
<p><strong>Dobryden, Paul</strong><br />
Cinema as Environment: The Emergence of German Film Culture</p>
<p><strong>Gordon, Kevin A.</strong><br />
Traces in the Desert: The Poetics of Sand, Dust and Ash in German Literature</p>
<p><strong>Manthripragada, Ashwin J.</strong><br />
Constituting a Self through an Indian Other. A Study of Select Works by Stefan Zweig and Hermann Hesse</p>
<p><strong>Musanovic, Emina</strong><br />
The Shadow: An Unruly Modern Specter</p>
<p>2013-2014</p>
<p><strong>Etzler, Melissa</strong><br />
Writing from the Periphery: W. G. Sebald and Outsider Art</p>
<p><strong>LeBlanc, Mary Ellen</strong><br />
Inheritance and Inflectional Morphology: Old High German, Latin, Early New High German, and Koine Greek</p>
<p>2012-2013</p>
<p><strong>Beals, Kurt</strong><br />
From Dada to Digital: Experimental Poetry in the Media Age</p>
<p><strong>Backman, Donald</strong><br />
The Topographic Imagination: Kerouac, Regener, Kafka and the Quest for Self-Realization</p>
<p><strong>Haubenreich, Jacob</strong><br />
The Materialities of Writing in Rilke’s The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge</p>
<p>2011-2012</p>
<p><strong>Kolar, Meredith</strong><br />
Cognitive Structures Underlying Gendered Language Usage in Germany: Narration and Linguistic Fieldwork<br />
Committee: Rauch, Shannon, Miller</p>
<p><strong>St. Clair, Michael</strong><br />
Germanic Origins from the Perspective of the Y-Chromosome<br />
Committee: Rauch, Shannon, Slatkin</p>
<p><strong>Zahrt, Jennifer</strong><br />
The Astrological Imaginary in Early Twentieth-Century German Culture<br />
Committee: Largier/Kaes, Sheehan</p>
<p>2010-2011</p>
<p><strong>Bergerson, Jeremy</strong><br />
Apperception and Linguistic Contact between German and Afrikaans<br />
Committee: Rauch/Shannon, Dewulf, Lindow</p>
<p><strong>Layne, Priscilla<br />
</strong>Black Voices, German Rebels: Acts of Masculinity in Postwar Popular Culture<br />
Committee: Göktürk, Kaes, Guilbault</p>
<p>2009-2010</p>
<p><strong>Huffmaster, Michael</strong><br />
Reading Kafka's Mind: Categories, Schemas, Metaphors<br />
Committee: Kramsch, Kaes, Largier, Sweetser</p>
<p><strong>Price, Timothy</strong><br />
The Old Saxon Leipzig Heliand Manuscript Fragment (MS L): New Evidence Concerning Luther, the Poet, and Ottonian Heritage<br />
Committee: Rauch, Shannon, Lindow</p>
<p><strong>Rahman, Sabrina</strong><br />
Designing Empire: Austria and the Applied Arts, 1864-1918<br />
Committee: Kaes, Tennant, Göktürk, Bernstein</p>
<p><strong>Sakalauskaite, Aida</strong><br />
Zoometaphors in English, German, and Lithuanian: A Corpus Study<br />
Committee: Rauch, Shannon, Frick</p>
<p><strong>Trop, Gabriel</strong><br />
Aesthetic Exercises and Poetic Form in the Works of Hölderlin, Novalis, and Rococo Poets<br />
Committee: Kudszus, Kaes, Largier, Kurke</p>
<p>2008-2009</p>
<p><strong>Gramling, David</strong><br />
Where Here Begins: Monolingualism and the Spatial Imagination<br />
Committee: Göktürk, Kaes, Kramsch, Hanks</p>
<p><strong>Henderson, Dayton</strong><br />
The Cult of Antigone Conflicts in Commemorating Germany’s Fallen Soldiers<br />
Committee: Kaes, Göktürk, Tennant, Sandberg</p>
<p><strong>Kooiker, Jason</strong><br />
Standard German and Dialect in the Swiss-German Classroom <strong><br />
</strong>Committee: Rauch, Shannon, Hinton</p>
<p><strong>Schechtman, Robert</strong><br />
Community and Utopia: The Discourse of Gemeinschaft and the Search for a New Modernity in Germany<br />
Committee: Kaes, Göktürk, Largier, Sandberg</p>
<p><strong>Yamini-Hamedani, Azadeh</strong><br />
Waves of Translation: Goethe, Hafez, Nietzsche, Zoroaster<br />
Committee: Kudszus<strong>,</strong> Rauch, Largier, Schwartz</p>
