Das Groteske in drei Parodien Thomas Manns: "Joseph und seine Brüder," "Das Gesetz," "Der Erwählte"</p>
<p><strong>Gray, Clayton</strong><br />
Motifs of Classical <em>Minnesang</em>: Their Origin, Content, and Development</p>
<p><strong>Rickerson, Earl Martin</strong><br />
The <em>lingua adamica</em>: Its Historical Development and Its Role in German Baroque Literature</p>
<p><strong>Stenberg, Peter Alvin</strong><br />
The Theme of Time and the Golden Age: A Study of Meister Eckhart, Novalis, and Hofmannsthal</p>
<p><strong>Waldenrath, Douglas Alexander</strong><br />
Gotthold Ephraim Lessing - the Humanist</p>
<p>1967-1968</p>
<p><strong>Bahr, Ehrhard Carl Oskar</strong><br />
"Diese sehr ernsten Scherze ..." - Studien zum Problem der Ironie in Goethes Spätwerk (<em>Divan</em>, <em>Wanderjahre</em> und <em>Faust II</em>)</p>
<p><strong>Clyde, Monica Weber</strong><br />
Der Bildungsgedanke bei Wilhelm Raabe</p>
<p><strong>Giegerich, Wolfgang</strong><br />
Der verlonene Sohn - vom Ursprung des Dichtens Wilhelm Raabes</p>
<p><strong>Hinman, Martha Mayo</strong><br />
Rhetoric and Ornamentation in the Songs of Walther von der Vogelweide</p>
<p><strong>Kudszus, Winfried</strong><br />
Ödipus der Sprache: zum sprachlichen Geschehen beim späten und spätesten Höderlin</p>
<p><strong>Ober, Peter Chapin</strong><br />
Sense Images for Noetic Experience in the Works of Meister Eckhart</p>
<p><strong>Read, Ralph Russell</strong><br />
The Politization of Modern German Historical Drama</p>
<p><strong>Richards, David Gleyre</strong><br />
The Works of George Büchner: A Study in Form and Meaning</p>
<p><strong>Wheelis, Samuel Millard</strong><br />
Nicodemus Frischlin: Comedian and Humanist</p>
<p>1966-1967</p>
<p><strong>Kluger, Ruth</strong><br />
The Development of the German Epigram in the 17th Century</p>
<p><strong>Pimentel, Raul</strong><br />
The German Historical Folksong of the Late Middle Ages</p>
<p><strong>Thomas, Barry Gillespie</strong><br />
Gottfried Keller: Appearance and Reality in his Prose Works</p>
<p>1965-1966</p>
<p><strong>Baron, Frank E.</strong><br />
The Beginnings of German Humanism: The Life and Work of the Wandering Humanist Peter Luder</p>
<p><strong>Bragg, Marvin Howell</strong><br />
The Concept of the Profession of Poet in Germany during the Eighteenth Century and the Evolution of a New Theory of Literature</p>
<p><strong>Maurer, Warren R.</strong><br />
The Naturalist Appraisal of German Literature</p>
<p><strong>Mihailovich, Vasa D.</strong><br />
Hermann Hesse and Russia</p>
<p><strong>Sullivan, John Herman</strong><br />
The German Religious Sonnet of the Seventeenth Century</p>
<p>1964-1965</p>
<p><strong>Fetzer, John F.</strong><br />
Music in the Life and Works of Clemens Brentano</p>
<p><strong>Lowe, Pardee Joe Yee</strong><br />
German Noun Formation, 1964: Suffixation</p>
<p><strong>Van Asselt, Jan</strong><br />
A Graphological Study of the Language of Zeno, a Middle Low German</p>
<p>1963-1964</p>
<p><strong>Feder, Murray Harold</strong><br />
A Source Study and Interpretation of the Middle High German Poem: Die Gute Frau</p>
<p><strong>Stavenhagen, Lee</strong><br />
The Science of Parzival</p>
<p>1962-1963</p>
<p><strong>Hertling, Gunter H.</strong><br />
Wandlung der Werte im dichterischen Werke der Ricarda Huch</p>
<p><strong>McWilliams, James R.</strong><br />
Thomas Mann's Heroes: Their Guilt and Its Significance</p>
<p>1961-1962</p>
<p><strong>Farquharson, Robert Howard</strong><br />
The Development of the Love Theme in the Works of Hermann Hesse</p>
<p><strong>Gish, Theodor Gordon</strong><br />
Immer nach Hause: The Theme of Wandering from Its Literary Beginnings Through Romanticism in Germany</p>
<p><strong>Mileck, Margrethe Schioler</strong><br />
Scandinavian Antiquity in German Literature from 1745 to 1773</p>
<p>1960-1961</p>
<p><strong>Brueckner, Hans-Dieter</strong><br />
Heldengestaltung in Conrad Ferdinand Meyers Prosawerken</p>
<p><strong>Hortenback, Jenny Christa</strong><br />
Freiheitsstreben und Destruktivität: Frauen in den Dramen August Stringbergs und Gerhart Hauptmanns</p>
<p>1959-1960</p>
<p><strong>Wiseman, Richard Wallace</strong><br />
Music and the Problem of Evil: Condemnation and Affirmation in the Works of Thomas Mann and Hermann Hesse</p>
<p>1958-1959</p>
<p><strong>Rosenau, Henriette</strong><br />
Die Symbolik im Werk der Dichterin Gertrud von Le Fort</p>
<p><strong>Spaethling, Robert Herbert</strong><br />
Der neue Stil im Drama des Sturm und Drangs</p>
<p>1957-1958</p>
<p><strong>McNeely, James Alexander</strong><br />
Political Themes in the Literature of the German Enlightenment</p>
<p>1956-1957</p>
<p><strong>Hauser, Ronald</strong><br />
Friedrich Hebbel and the Storm and Stress</p>
<p><strong>Logan, Alan Livingston</strong><br />
The Attitude of the Early Nietzsche toward German Literature</p>
<p><strong>Richter, Glenda Gillard</strong><br />
Daniel Casper von Lohenstein and the Turks</p>
<p><strong>Tubach, Frederic Christian</strong><br />
History of the Exemplum in Germany to 1500</p>
<p>1955-1956</p>
<p><strong>Babcock, Leland Stillman</strong><br />
Concepts of the Good Life in Stifter's Early Works</p>
<p><strong>Blaisdell, Foster Warren</strong><br />
The Preposition-Adverbs in the Oldest Icelandic Prose Manuscripts</p>
<p><strong>Dunkle, Harvey Ivan</strong><br />
C.M. Wieland's Aesthetic Evaluation of Literature</p>
<p><strong>Engelsing, Ingeborg</strong><br />
"Amor fati" in Zuckmayers Dramen, 1925-1955</p>
<p><strong>Iiams, Carlton Laird</strong><br />
Aegidiu Albertinus and Antonio de Guevara</p>
<p><strong>Richter, Leo Thomas</strong><br />
The Italian Influence upon German Letters during the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Centuries</p>
<p><strong>Taylor, Ransom Theodore</strong><br />
The Concept of Political Power in the Works of Alfred Neumann</p>
<p>1954-1955</p>
<p><strong>Daviau, Donald George</strong><br />
The Significance of Hermann Bahr to Austria</p>
<p><strong>Shetter, William Z.</strong><br />
Umlaut in Medieval Dutch Nonliterary Texts</p>
<p>1953-1954</p>
<p><strong>Henningsen, Caroline Henrietta</strong><br />
The East Frisian Dialect of Point Pleasant, Sacramento County, California</p>
<p><strong>Shaw, Leroy Robert</strong><br />
The Concept of 'Kulturluge' in Hauptmann's Early Works</p>
<p><strong>Wilbur, Terence Harrison</strong><br />
A Study of the Magical Vocabulary of Common Germanic</p>
<p>1952-1953</p>
<p><strong>Nicholls, Roger Archibald</strong><br />
Early Thomas Mann and Nietzsche</p>
<p><strong>Wilkie, Richard Francis</strong><br />
Christian Felix Weisze and his Relation to French and English Literature</p>
<p>1949-1950</p>
<p><strong>Goldsmith, Ulrich Karl</strong><br />
The Will to Power in the Poetical Genesis of Stefan George</p>
<p><strong>Kraft, Walter Carl</strong><br />
The Phonology of Wittenweiler's Ring</p>
<p><strong>Schmidt, S. Edgar</strong><br />
German Librettos and Librettists from Postel's <em>Psyche</em> (1701) to Schikaneder's <em>Zauberflote</em> (1794)</p>
<p>1948-1949</p>
<p><strong>Height, Joseph S.</strong><br />
The Translation of Goethe's Lyric Poems into English</p>
<p>1947-1948</p>
<p><strong>Bergel, Kurt [ed.]</strong><br />
Der Briefwechsel von Georg Brandes und Arthur Schnitzler</p>
<p><strong>Roeger, William Albert [ed.]</strong><br />
Georg Hager's <em>Zweites Liederbuch</em>: a Sixteenth Century Anthology of <em>Meistergesang</em></p>
<p><strong>Sobel, Eli</strong><br />
A Hans Sachs Anthology: The Meistertöne of Berlin 414</p>
<p>1946-1947</p>
<p><strong>Brown, Francis Andrew</strong><br />
The Ideas of John Locke in the German <em>Aufklärung</em></p>
<p><strong>Lombardi, Stephanie Orth</strong><br />
Josef von Sonnenfels and the Viennese stage</p>
<p><strong>Roertgen, William Francis</strong><br />
The Frankfurter gelehrte Anzeigen in Relation to the Literature of the Time (1772-1790)</p>
<p>1943-1944</p>
<p><strong>Hagge, Carl William</strong><br />
Gabriel Rollenhagen's <em>Amantes Amentes</em>: An Introduction and Notes to the Edition of 1614</p>
<p><strong>Riordan, John Lancaster</strong><br />
The Pleier's Place in German Arthurian Literature</p>
<p>1942-1943</p>
<p><strong>Brenninger, Ralph Alfred</strong><br />
A Study of the Fugger Financial Vocabulary, 1494-1525</p>
<p>1941-1942</p>
<p><strong>Moeller, Eric</strong><br />
Poetic Style and Technique in the Heroic Lays of the Edda</p>
<p><strong>Whitesell, Frederick Rhodes</strong><br />
Middle High German Text Publication, 1800-1856</p>
<p>1940-1941</p>
<p><strong>Immerwahr, Raymond Max</strong><br />
Ludwig Tieck's Contribution in Theory and Practice to the German Romanticists' Conception of Comedy</p>
<p>1937-1938</p>
<p><strong>Cohn, Fritz Ludwig</strong><br />
France and the Poetry of the German <em>Vormärz</em></p>
<p><strong>Engelbarts, Rudolf Karl Wilhelm</strong><br />
Karl Rosenkranz als Literaturhistoriker und Kritiker</p>
<p>1936-1937</p>
<p><strong>Borden, Charles Ernest</strong><br />
Johann Elias Schlegel als Vorläufer Gotthold Ephrain Lessings</p>
<p>1935-1936</p>
<p><strong>Melz, Fritz</strong><br />
Wieland und Tieck: Ein Vergleich</p>
<p><strong>Schmitz, Frederick Josef</strong><br />
Lessings Stellung in der Entfaltung des Individualismus im 18. Jahrhundert</p>
<p>1934-1935</p>
<p><strong>Bunje, Emil Theodore Hieronymus</strong><br />
A Reconsideration of the Main Difficulties in the Expository Part of the <em>Hildebrandslied</em></p>
<p>1933-1934</p>
<p><strong>Delfs, Annemarie Helene</strong><br />
Die politische Lyrik des Dreissigjährigen Krieges von 1618-1648</p>
<p><strong>Harrison, Margaret (Hayne)</strong><br />
A Comparative Study of Modern Religious Drama in Germany and France</p>
<p>1925-1926</p>
<p><strong>King, Henry Safford</strong><br />
Echoes of the American Revolution in German Literature</p>
<p>1924-1925</p>
<p><strong>MacInnes, Isabel Stewart</strong><br />
The Influence of Feminism on the German Women Novelists</p>
<p>1922-1923</p>
<p><strong>Gudde, Erwin Gustav</strong><br />
Freiligraths Entwicklung als politischer Dichter</p>
<p><strong>Kleine, Mathilde</strong><br />
Zur Entwicklung der Futurumschreibung 'Werden' mit dem Infinitiv</p>
<p>1919-1920</p>
<p><strong>Bell, Clair Hadyen</strong><br />
The Sister's Son in the Medieval German Epic</p>
<p><strong>Reinsch, Frank Herman</strong><br />
Goethe's Political Interests prior to 1787</p>
<p>1912</p>
<p><strong>Wyneken, Friedrich Alexander</strong><br />
Rousseaus Einfluss auf Klinger</p>
<p>1908</p>
<p><strong>Pinger, Wilhelm Robert Richard</strong><br />
Der junge Goethe und das Publikum</p>

	<article id="post-418" class="post-418 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Placement</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The department has an outstanding placement record. Over the last decade, PhDs in German accepted tenure-track or long-term positions at the following institutions: The University of Arizona, Brigham Young University, Georgetown University, University of Illinois at Chicago, Southern Illinois University, Indiana University/Purdue University, University of Maryland, McGill University in Montreal, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Ohio State University, University of Rochester, University of Virginia, University of Washington at Seattle, and Washington University in St. Louis.</p>
<p>The department is committed to helping students secure appointments in academia. This effort includes a workshop on all aspects of the academic job market early in each fall semester, reviewing of curriculum vitae and letters of application, mock interviews, and follow-up advising.</p>
<p><strong>Placements by Year </strong>(since 2010)</p>
<p>2015-16</p>
<p>Born, Erik [Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship at the Society for the Humanities, Cornell University]<br />
Dobryden, Paul [Asst. Prof., University of Virginia]<br />
Ellis, Robin [Visiting Asst. Prof. Davidson College]<br />
Mušanović, Emina [Asst. Prof., Linfield College]</p>
<p>2014-15</p>
<p>Allred, Mason [Historian and Editor, The Joseph Smith Papers]<br />
<a href="http://lsa.umich.edu/german/people/faculty/dickins.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dickinson, Kristin</a> [Asst. Prof., University of Michigan]<br />
Gordon, Kevin A. [Instructional Designer, UCLA Extension]</p>
<p>2013-14</p>
<p><a href="http://www.zfl-berlin.org/personenliste-detail/items/almog.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Almog, Yael</a> [Asst. Prof., Center of Literary and Cultural Research in Berlin (ZfL)]<br />
Etzler, Melissa [Instructor, Butler University]<br />
<a href="http://www.hws.edu/academics/german/facultyProfile.aspx?facultyID=1228">Manthripragada, Ashwin</a> [Visiting Asst. Prof., Hobart and William Smith Colleges]</p>
<p>2012-13</p>
<p><a href="http://german.wustl.edu/people/kurt-beals" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Beals, Kurt</a> [Asst. Prof., Washington University in St. Louis]<br />
Haubenreich, Jacob [Asst. Prof., Southern Illinois University]<br />
<a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/instructor/jkooiker" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Kooiker, Jason</a> [Lecturer, Stanford Language Center]</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 16px;">2011-12</span></p>
<p><a href="http://www.morris.umn.edu/academics/german/faculty/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dewey, Tonya</a> [Asst. Prof., University of Minnesota, Morris]<br />
Kolar, Meredith [Lecturer, University of Zürich]<br />
<a href="http://layne.web.unc.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Layne, Priscilla</a> [Asst. Prof., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]<br />
Price, Timothy [Research Fellow, University Frankfurt, Germany]<br />
St. Clair, Michael [Lecturer, UC Berkeley]</p>
<p>2010-11</p>
<p><a href="http://german.arizona.edu/people/david-gramling" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Gramling, David</a> [Asst. Prof., The University of Arizona]<br />
<a href="http://trop.web.unc.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Trop, Gabriel</a> [Asst. Prof., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">The following  is a list of current positions of graduates:</span></strong></p>
<p><a href="https://germanics.washington.edu/people/eric-ames" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Ames, Eric</a> [Prof., University of Washington]<br />
Ascárate, Richard [Visiting Asst. Prof., George Washington University]<br />
<a href="http://www.fau.edu/german/augustyn.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Augustyn, Prisca</a> [Prof., Florida Atlantic University]<br />
Baackmann, Susanne [Assoc. Prof., University of New Mexico]<br />
Berman, Nina [ Prof., Ohio State University]<br />
Blumberg, David [Chair of Department of World Languages, Campolindo High School, Moraga, CA]<br />
<a href="https://germanic.osu.edu/people/byram.4" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Byram, Katra</a> [Asst. Prof., Ohio State University]<br />
Clarke, Robert [Teaching Fellow, UC Berkeley]<br />
Cleek, John [Lecturer, UC Berkeley]<br />
Coffey, Michael [Lecturer, UC Berkeley]<br />
Collier Sy-Quia, Hilary [Ermitage International School France]<br />
<a href="http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/filmstudies/staff_profiles/dr-michael-cowan/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Cowan, Michael</a> [Reader, University of St. Andrews]<br />
Cudahy, Mary [Asst. Prof., Southern Illinois University, Carbondale]<br />
<a href="https://german.wustl.edu/people/erlin_matt" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Erlin, Matthew</a> [Prof., Washington University, St. Louis]<br />
<a href="http://lcsl.uic.edu/germanic/people/faculty/sara-hall" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Hall, Sara</a> [Assoc. Prof., University of Illinois, Chicago]<br />
<a href="http://german.ucdavis.edu/people/profile/106" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Harjes, Kirsten</a> [Lecturer, UC Davis]<br />
Howell, Tess [Adjunct Prof. Southern Methodist University]<br />
Huffmaster, Michael [Assistant Professor at the Universidad de Puerto Rico — Mayagüez]<br />
<a href="http://www.sas.rochester.edu/mlc/people/faculty/hwang_june/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Hwang, June</a> [Assoc. Prof., University of Rochester]<br />
<a href="https://www.newschool.edu/nssr/faculty/noah-isenberg/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Isenberg, Noah</a> [Prof., The New School Eugene Lang College]<br />
<a href="https://german.wustl.edu/people/kapczynski_jennifer" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Kapczynski, Jennifer</a> [Assoc. Prof., Washington University]<br />
Kopp, Kristin [Assoc. Prof., University of Missouri]<br />
<a href="http://sllc.umd.edu/user/jkoser" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Koser, Julie</a> [Assoc. Prof., University of Maryland]<br />
<a href="http://hsp.arizona.edu/professor/barbara-kosta" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Kosta, Barbara</a> [Assoc. Prof., The University of Arizona]<br />
Lagrone, Emily Banwell [Freelance Translator, Oakland, CA]<br />
McFarland, Robert [Assoc. Prof., Brigham Young]<br />
McCormick, Richard [Professor, University of Minnesota]<br />
<a href="http://german.cofc.edu/about/faculty-and-staff/nenno-nancy.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Nenno, Nancy</a> [Assoc. Prof., College of Charleston]<br />
<a href="https://germanic.osu.edu/people/reitter.4" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Reitter, Paul</a> [Prof., Ohio State University]<br />
<a href="http://www.ipfw.edu/departments/coas/depts/ilcs/about/faculty-roberts.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Roberts, Lee</a> [Assoc. Prof., Indiana University/Purdue University]<br />
<a href="https://www.ipfw.edu/departments/coas/depts/ilcs/about/faculty-sroberts.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Roberts, Suin</a> [Assoc. Prof., Indiana University/Purdue University at Fort Wayne]<br />
Sakalauskaite, Aida [Instructor, College of Alameda]<br />
<a href="https://dlcl.stanford.edu/people/kathryn-starkey?q=people/kathryn-starkey" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Starkey, Kathryn</a> [Prof., Stanford University]<br />
Toth, Gergely [Assoc. Instructor, University of Utah]<br />
<a href="http://german.arizona.edu/people/warnerc" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Warner, Chantelle</a> [Assoc. Prof., The University of Arizona]<br />
<a href="http://www.german.virginia.edu/faculty/profile/mcw9d" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Wellmon, Chad</a> [Assoc. Prof., University of Virginia]<br />
Whitt, Jason [Research Fellow, University of Nottingham]<br />
<a href="http://kwiliarty.php.wesleyan.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Wiliarty, Kevin</a> [Academic Technology Coordinator., Wesleyan University]<br />
Yamini-Hamedani, Azadeh [Asst. Prof., Simon Fraser University, Canada]</p>
<p>Last updated on 05/17/2016.</p>

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2598" class="post-2598 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Teaching &#038; Pedagogy</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Fully committed to promoting excellence in teaching, the German Department emphasizes the thorough pedagogical and professional development of Graduate Student Instructors (GSIs). All of our graduate students have ample opportunity to teach in a vibrant and innovative language program while receiving extensive training in teaching language and culture at the beginning, intermediate, and advanced levels. The pedagogical issues raised reach beyond the language classroom to students’ future roles as professors of literature and linguistics. By reflecting on their own teaching practice and its relationship to current theory, our graduate students are prepared for a strong start on the job market and for continuous professional development throughout their teaching careers.</p>
<p>GSIs begin teaching one section per semester of a lower-division German course (first- through fourth-semester language instruction, usually beginning with German 1). Later in their careers they can also apply to teach courses in conversation, German for reading knowledge, and Reading and Composition. The latter courses (offered in English on German topics) are especially important after the QE, as they allow students to teach literature and devise their own syllabi. These courses also let them test out their ideas—often derived from their dissertations—with a small group of bright freshmen and sophomores.</p>
<p>Most classes meet 50 minutes per day, five days a week. Beyond daily classroom teaching, GSI duties include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Attend regularly the weekly group meetings of all instructors and the course coordinator.</li>
<li>Develop your own lesson plans in accordance with the course syllabus distributed by the coordinator.</li>
<li>Share with your group whatever supplementary materials you develop for effective classroom teaching (visuals, grammar handouts, supplementary readings, charts, group tasks, etc.).</li>
<li>Design portions of the quizzes and the final exams.</li>
<li>Administer, grade, and return students’ work (homework and tests) in a timely manner.</li>
<li>Follow the grading criteria agreed upon by your group.</li>
<li>Attend a “post-mortem” meeting of your group at the end of the semester.</li>
<li>Read carefully the evaluations submitted by your students after you have submitted their final grades. These evaluations constitute valuable feedback on your performance as a teacher.</li>
</ul>
<p>Evaluation of your effectiveness as a teacher will be based not only upon your classroom performance (as assessed by faculty and coordinator visits), but also upon your fulfillment of the above obligations. Your reappointment as a GSI will also depend upon your fulfillment of these obligations.</p>
<p><strong>Distinguishing Features</strong></p>
<p>Our core development sequence for professional development goes far beyond that offered by most graduate programs and includes the following components:</p>
<ul>
<li>A three-day, interactive pre-semester orientation and workshop for all new GSIs.</li>
<li>One day of refresher workshops for continuing GSIs at the beginning of each semester.</li>
<li>Two three-unit pedagogical seminars on Teaching College German: German 350 and 351, which focus on the theory and practice of foreign language pedagogy.</li>
<li>Weekly practicum/coordination meetings in which issues related to syllabus development, lesson plans, assessment questions, etc., are discussed.</li>
<li>Peer, coordinator, and faculty observations on a regular basis.</li>
<li>A stimulating atmosphere of mentorship and collaboration through continuous professional development and innovation linked to a dynamic language program.</li>
<li>Unique opportunities for funded research and further professional development through the <a title="Berkeley Language Center" href="http://blc.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Berkeley Language Center</a> and the university’s <a href="http://gsi.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">GSI Teaching and Resource Center</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p><b>Bridging Theory and Practice: Language Pedagogy Seminars</b></p>
<p>The first semester of the language pedagogy seminar (German 350, see <a href="/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/German-350-Sample-Syllabus.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">sample syllabus</a>) focuses on principles of teaching methodology, research in Second Language Acquisition, skill-specific techniques, assessment, roles and tasks in the classroom, teaching culture, and approaches to critical reflection. The second semester (German 351, see <a href="/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/German-351-Sample-Syllabus.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">sample syllabus</a>) looks toward the teaching of intermediate and advanced language/culture courses. Instructional technologies, teaching writing, teaching the literary text, and issues in curriculum design form the main topics, with a continued emphasis on current research and critical reflection. In addition, each course includes a practical component in which graduate student instructors relate the seminar principles to current classroom activities, receive guidance, exchange materials, and generally coordinate their teaching efforts.</p>
<p><strong>Gaining Experience: Teaching Opportunities</strong></p>
<p>In the course of their studies, graduate students have the opportunity to teach a broad range of courses. Generally, all GSIs will teach at least the first two years of German (German 1-4). This experience alone covers a range from communicative teaching of the basics to content-<br />
based instruction with an emphasis on critical inquiry into the nature of language and culture.</p>
<p>Other teaching opportunities include conversation courses, German for Reading Knowledge, a German gender perspectives course, and the freshman composition courses R5A and R5B. The latter are taught in English and include extensive readings of German literature in translation on a topic developed by the instructor.</p>
<p><strong>Supporting Professional Development: Courses and Centers</strong></p>
<p>The campus offers a rich and unique support system for the professional and intellectual development of teachers. The <a href="http://gsi.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">GSI Teaching and Resource Center</a> (director: Linda von Hoene) and the <a title="Berkeley Language Center" href="http://blc.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Berkeley Language Center</a> (director: Rick Kern) offer a range of pedagogical workshops and lecture series which regularly feature world-renowned researchers in the fields of Second Language Acquisition and Applied Linguistics, as well as stimulating panel discussions and seminars on issues directly relevant to language teaching and learning at Berkeley and in other institutional contexts. In addition, the BLC offers up to six graduate research fellowships each year to conduct research on ways to improve instruction in any of the languages taught on the Berkeley campus.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

		<script type="text/javascript">
			window._wpemojiSettings = {"baseUrl":"https:\/\/s.w.org\/images\/core\/emoji\/2.2.1\/72x72\/","ext":".png","svgUrl":"https:\/\/s.w.org\/images\/core\/emoji\/2.2.1\/svg\/","svgExt":".svg","source":{"concatemoji":"http:\/\/german.berkeley.edu\/wp-includes\/js\/wp-emoji-release.min.js?ver=4.7.5"}};

	<article id="post-2582" class="post-2582 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Resources</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The department has curated a variety of resources that may be of service to prospective, current, and past undergraduate and graduate students, as well as to interested members of the community.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->

	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-271" class="post-271 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Campus and Local Resources</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The strength of the German program at Berkeley is greatly enhanced by the excellence of other departments at the university. The most recent National Research Council survey reported that Berkeley has more top-ranked doctoral programs than any other university in the nation. Thirty-five of Berkeley's thirty-six PhD programs were ranked in the top ten of their field. From Art History to Music, Political Science and Rhetoric to Architecture and Linguistics, the reputation of the Berkeley campus is not easily matched by any institution of higher education in the world.</p>
<p>The department also benefits from a wide variety of organizations on campus—the <a title="Institute of European Studies" href="http://ies.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Institute of European Studies</a>, the <a title="Berkeley Language Center" href="http://blc.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Berkeley Language Center</a>, the <a title="Berkeley Linguistics Society" href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/bls/" target="_blank">Berkeley Linguistics Society</a>, the <a title="Townsend Center" href="http://townsendcenter.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Townsend Center for the Humanities</a>, and the <a title="Center for Studies in Higher Education" href="http://www.cshe.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Center for Studies in Higher Education</a>. The recently established <a title="UC Consortium for Language Learning and Teaching" href="http://uccllt.ucdavis.edu/" target="_blank">UC Consortium for Language Learning and Teaching</a>, of which Berkeley is a member, affords all those involved in the practice and the theory of second language acquisition an opportunity to share resources and intellectual events.</p>
<p>The <a title="PFA" href="http://bampfa.berkeley.edu/filmseries/" target="_blank">Pacific Film Archive</a>, the <a title="Berkeley Repertory Theater" href="http://www.berkeleyrep.org/" target="_blank">Berkeley Repertory Theater</a>, and the <a title="Magnes Museum" href="http://www.magnes.org/" target="_blank">Judah L. Magnes Jewish Museum</a> are within walking distance from the campus. The <a title="Goethe Institut San Francisco" href="http://www.goethe.de/ins/us/saf/enindex.htm" target="_blank">Goethe Institute</a> is located in nearby San Francisco.</p>
<p>The Main Library contains roughly nine million volumes, with the Germanic collection alone comprising nearly 800,000 volumes. These holdings make it possible to do original research based on excellent primary sources. They are complemented by the collections of the libraries at the Graduate Theological Union, Stanford University, UCLA, and the other UC campuses, with which Berkeley has reciprocal borrowing arrangements. Our sizable departmental library includes a substantial video collection of German films and a viewing station, as well as recent German newspapers, magazines, and periodicals. It is an inviting place to read and relax.</p>
<p>The intellectual life on campus—with its steady stream of internationally renowned speakers, symposia, conferences, and (maintaining Berkeley's reputation from the 1960s) rallies in support of local and global causes—is unique. Dozens of working groups, sponsored by the Humanities Center and made up of students and faculty from different departments, meet regularly to explore topics of particular interest. These have proved most effective in fostering intellectual exchange across disciplines and academic cultures within the Berkeley community. Students in the German Department have initiated two of these working groups, one on German idealism and another on the emergence of modernity.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">

	</header><!-- #masthead -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2624" class="post-2624 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Commencement</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>WHAT</strong>: 2018 Commencement ceremony for the following participating departments: Celtic Studies, Comparative Literature, French, German, Italian Studies Program, Scandinavian, Slavic, and Spanish &amp; Portuguese.</p>
<p><strong>WHEN</strong>: Monday, May 14, 2018, from 2:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.</p>
<p><strong>WHERE</strong>: Ceremony will take place at the Zellerbach Playhouse.</p>
<p><strong>WHO</strong>: Students completing their BA, MA, and PhD degrees in Fall 2017 and Spring, Summer, or Fall 2018. Students may participate only once.</p>
<p><strong>What you need to know:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>KEYNOTE SPEAKER: TBA</li>
<li>MASTER OF CEREMONIES: TBA</li>
<li>DEGREE LIST (Undergraduates only): N/A</li>
<li>DIPLOMAS: Diplomas will be available at 120 Sproul Hall approximately four months after your “official” graduation. There is a form to fill out and a fee to pay if you request that your diploma be mailed to you. See the <a title="Office of the Registrar" href="http://registrar.berkeley.edu/Records/transdipl.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Office of the Registrar</a> for more information.</li>
<li>CEREMONY: The ceremony will run for approximately two to two-and-a-half hours, with a main speaker, a (very) brief presentation by each department, and the conferral of each department's degrees.</li>
<li>TICKETS: TBA</li>
<li>PHOTOGRAPHY: GradImages is the official photographer for this ceremony. Students participating in Commencement are asked to pre-register for the “University of CA Berkeley Languages” ceremony with GradImages so that they can be contacted after the ceremony. All students who have pre-registered will receive their picture proofs via email within 24 hours. Each email will contain the student’s pin number, which can be used to access that student’s pictures on GradImages’ website. Students will also receive a picture proof in the mail 3-5 business days after the commencement ceremony. Students who would like their proof to be sent to any family members or friends are welcome to visit GradImages to register those family members or friends. There are two ways to order, <a href="https://www.gradimages.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">online</a> or by phone at 1-800-261-2576.</li>
<li>RECEPTION: TBA</li>
<li>REGALIA: Cap and gown sets are available for purchase only through the Special Services Department at the Cal Student Store (510-642-9000, extension 681) beginning in late March and continuing through May. The charge for BA regalia is approximately $50.00; for MA regalia, it is $99; and for PhD regalia, it is $123. PhD candidates who wish to purchase official regalia may do so through the <a href="https://calstudentstore.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Cal Student Store</a>.</li>
<li>ANNOUNCEMENTS: Graduation announcements are formal notices to send to family and friends announcing your graduation. Announcements come in two forms: generic or personalized. For more information, see the <a title="eFollett" href="http://www.bkstr.com/calberkeleystore/home" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">eFollett website</a>.</li>
<li>PARKING: We will post more information closer to the commencement date. In the meantime, visit the campus <a title="Parking &amp; Transportation" href="http://pt.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Parking &amp; Transportation website</a> for information.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Contact Information for Various Departments:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Comparative Literature: Tony Soyka</li>
<li>German &amp; Dutch: <a href="/author/nsamadi/">Nadia Samadi</a></li>
<li>Spanish &amp; Portuguese: Jenny Cole</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Related Information</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://commencement.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Campus Convocation</a></li>
<li><a href="http://californians.berkeley.edu/events.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Senior Week</a></li>
<li><a href="http://visitberkeley.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">City of Berkeley Visitor Center</a></li>
</ul>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2622" class="post-2622 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Resources</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Degree Information</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/DOCTORAL-STUDENTS-FILING-CHECKLIST.pdf" target="_blank">Guidelines for Submitting a Doctoral Dissertation or a Master’s Thesis</a> (PDF)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/policies/forms.shtml" target="_blank">Applications and Forms</a></li>
<li><a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/gradappeal.pdf" target="_blank">Graduate Appeal Procedure</a></li>
<li><a style="font-style: normal" href="http://summer.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Summer Sessions</a></li>
<li><a style="font-style: normal" href="https://bearfacts.berkeley.edu/bearfacts/" target="_blank">Bear Facts</a></li>
<li><a style="font-style: normal" href="https://telebears.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Tele-Bears</a></li>
<li><a style="font-style: normal" href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Schedule of Courses</a></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fellowships and Grants</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/financial/deadlines.shtml" target="_blank">Graduate Fellowship Deadlines</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-5777" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5777"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/people/">People</a></li>

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2615" class="post-2615 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Library Collections</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Collections</strong></p>
<p><a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Main Library</a><br />
<a href="http://oskicat.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Main Library Catalog</a><br />
<a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/" target="_blank">Media Resources Center</a><br />
<a href="http://guides.lib.berkeley.edu/c.php?g=4418&amp;p=15649" target="_blank">German Library Resources</a></p>
<p><strong>The University Library and the Germanic Collections</strong></p>
<p>The Germanic Collections of the University Library are among the most varied and extensive American collections of research materials in the humanities and social sciences from Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and the Scandinavian countries. As part of an overall University Library collection of more than 9 million volumes, the Germanic Collections currently number approximately 780,000 volumes and are growing at the rate of approximately 12,000 volumes per year. They span all periods of German, Dutch, and Scandinavian publishing, with special strength in Germanic literature and linguistics, including many first editions and rare books in those fields.</p>
<p>In addition to literature, literary theory, and language, the collections also exhibit exceptional strength in history, philosophy, sociology, political science, cinema, and popular culture. The holdings of primary and secondary works from the age of Goethe, the Weimar Republic, and contemporary German literature (including especially the works of non-native authors writing in German) are considered to be among the strongest in US research libraries. The University Library also holds extensive runs of newspapers and scholarly journals (in print, microform, and digital form) dating in some cases back to the 18th century and including dozens of newspapers from more than 40 cities in the German- and Dutch-speaking countries of Europe and in Scandinavia. In addition, thanks to its close ties to educational and research institutions in the former German Democratic Republic (Deutsche Demokratische Republik, or DDR), the library possesses the largest collection of material on the DDR among US research libraries.</p>
<p>The Germanic Collections have been built through a combination of extensive acquisition through purchase of new commercially-available materials, a far-reaching system of exchange agreements with more than 450 scholarly institutions in the countries listed above (including many in the former DDR), and an active program of gift solicitation from scholars and research institutions.</p>
<p>The University Library’s catalogs and Internet resources are available online, around the clock, worldwide at no charge to Berkeley students and faculty, and its holdings are represented in the major US and international online union catalogs. Berkeley’s students and faculty also have user privileges at both Stanford University Library and the libraries of the seven other University of California campuses, including the extensive Germanic collections of UCLA’s Research Library. Berkeley’s library is an active participant in national and international interlibrary lending, and its unique Germanic materials are in heavy demand by scholars at other institutions. The Germanic Collections have been the beneficiaries of numerous federal and private enrichment grants, many of which have been used to strengthen the University Library’s holdings of rarely-held ephemeral materials.</p>
<p><strong>Special Collections</strong></p>
<p>The University Library’s collections have been enhanced by the following purchases or gifts: the Bukofzer Library (ca. 1,000 volumes in German literature); the Burdach Library (ca. 6,700 volumes, strong in Medieval and Renaissance literary materials from Germany); the German 17th century and 18th century Literature Collection (many rare translations of 18th century classics from English to German, important poetical handbooks, runs of poetry journals from German-speaking Europe); the Bremer Library (ca. 3,000 volumes with special strength in 17th century German language and etymology, phonetics, phonology, modern German dialects and Frisian language and literature); the Hesse Archives (purchased in 1959; the most complete collection of materials on Hermann Hesse in the world, containing more than 1,400 items including books, the scores of musical settings for Hesse’s poems, newspaper and magazine clippings, pamphlets, phonograph recordings, translations into foreign languages, and extensive secondary literature on Hesse); the Loomis Collection (106 volumes and numerous pamphlets relative to Baroque and Renaissance literature in Germany, including many first editions and scarce materials from the earliest period in German printing); one of the most extensive collections in the world of Dutch Underground Press materials from the period of German occupation in the Netherlands during World War II; and the Weinhold Library, the cornerstone of Berkeley’s collections of rare and scarce literary materials, which consists of around 10,000 volumes on all periods and genres of German literature (especially rich in early and first editions).</p>
<p>In 1995, the library acquired the private collection of Martin Bircher, which details the history and activities of the Fruchtbringende Gesellschaft, Germany’s oldest learned society. It contains more than 600 early printed works, 300 manuscript items, and 300 pictorial items related to the society’s scope of activities in the 17th century; it is an invaluable source for the study of Early Modern German literature. In 2000, the University Library absorbed the holdings of the now-defunct Goethe Institute Library in San Francisco.</p>
<p><strong>Media Resources Center</strong></p>
<p>The library’s Media Resources Center is one of the largest collections of videos in a US academic library. Located on the basement floor of Moffitt Library, the collection includes more than 20,000 videos, more than 1,000 DVDs, and more than 3,000 spoken-word audio tapes. Holdings comprise over 500 German language films, including feature films, literary and dramatic adaptions, and documentary works. The feature collection includes more than 50 DDR films produced by the DEFA studios during the period 1950-1980.</p>
<p>The center maintains an extensive <a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/" target="_blank">website</a> that includes listings and descriptions of the center's holdings, including their feature films, videos on German history, life, and culture, and German WWII propaganda films. The website also contains extensive bibliographies of books and journal articles related to German film.</p>
<p>For further information regarding Media Resources Center collections or use policies, you may visit the center in person or submit a request by way of the center's <a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/commentform.html" target="_blank">online contact form</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Digital Collections</strong></p>
<p>Berkeley’s library has assembled an extensive collection of German Studies materials in digital form, including complete editions of many major literary and historical figures such as Brecht, Kafka, Goethe, Schiller, and Luther, monumental sets such as the Monumenta Germaniae Historica, standard reference materials such as dictionaries, encyclopedias, indexes, and directories, links to international Internet sites providing scholarly information for German Studies, online newspapers and scholarly journals, and many other types of digital content. An overview of these materials can be seen at the Library’s Germanic Collections <a href="http://guides.lib.berkeley.edu/c.php?g=4418&amp;p=15649" target="_blank">homepage</a>.</p>
<p>Librarian <a href="mailto:jott@berkeley.edu">Jeremy Ott</a> is currently in charge of the Germanic Collections. He is available to assist members of the Department of German with research questions and book orders. Please direct your purchase suggestions and questions to him or use the online <a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/using-the-libraries/recommend-purchase-form" target="_blank">purchase recommendation form</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Departmental Library</strong></p>
<p>The departmental library has a substantial collection of all major German writers and philosophers from the Middle Ages to the present. All authors on the PhD reading list are represented with their collected works and selected secondary literature. In addition, the departmental library boasts a sizable collection of books on Germanic linguistics, literary theory, cultural theory, and intellectual history.</p>
<p>We also have sections for Yiddish literature, feminism, and multicultural studies as well as German history and politics, art history and architecture, and cinema. Of course, the library has the latest reference works, dictionaries, and bibliographies. In addition to this, the departmental library owns a video and dvd collection of all major German films.</p>
<p>Periodicals include all journals of American German Studies (German Quarterly, Germanic Review, German Studies Review, Monatshefte, Colloquia Germanica), as well as such periodicals as Merkur, Neue Rundschau, Signs, PMLA, and Representations, among others. We carry such newspapers and magazines as Die Zeit, Spiegel, and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. Comfortable chairs and free coffee provide an atmosphere conducive to browsing and reading.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2620" class="post-2620 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Undergraduate Resources</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Advising, Registration, and Information</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://ls.berkeley.edu/undergraduates" target="_blank">Letters &amp; Sciences Undergraduate Student site</a></li>
<li><a href="http://ls-advise.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Letters &amp; Sciences Undergraduate Advising</a></li>
<li><a href="http://isf.ugis.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Undergraduate and Interdisciplinary Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="http://summer.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Summer Sessions</a></li>
<li><a href="https://bearfacts.berkeley.edu/bearfacts/" target="_blank">Bear Facts</a></li>
<li><a href="https://telebears.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Tele-Bears</a></li>
<li><a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Schedule of Courses</a></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Research</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://research.berkeley.edu/index.php" target="_blank">Undergraduate Research at Berkeley</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/instruct/" target="_blank">"Know Your Library" Workshops</a></li>
<li><a href="http://research.berkeley.edu/urap/" target="_blank">Undergraduate Research Apprentice Program</a></li>
<li><a href="http://hsp.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">Haas Scholars Program</a></li>
<li><a href="http://surf.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">SURF: Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowships</a></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Career</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://career.berkeley.edu/International/International.stm" target="_blank">International Career Field</a> (Career Center)</li>
<li><a href="http://research.berkeley.edu/travel/" target="_blank">Travel Grants for Undergraduate Research</a></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Student Resources</strong></p>
<ul>

			<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="nav-menu"><li id="menu-item-5776" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5776"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/about/">About</a></li>

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-2578" class="post-2578 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Undergraduate</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><strong>Undergraduate Studies Overview</strong></p>
<p>Our German Undergraduate Program offers a wide selection of <a href="/courses/">courses</a> covering German-speaking culture from the Middle Ages to the present. The department provides classes in German and English on language, literature, linguistics, philosophy, history, and media.<a href="/Users/Annika/Downloads/Desktop/CONTENT%20REDESIGN_Undergraduate%20Pages_revised%20CCJ_Oct28%202013.docx#_msocom_1"><br />
</a></p>
<p>Our students are challenged to gain fluency as well as cultural competency in the German language, read major works by renowned authors such as Kafka, Freud, and Nietzsche, learn about Medieval society, German Romanticism, Weimar cinema, the Nazi past, and multicultural Germany, and explore a variety of topics including Medieval epics, Storm and Stress poetry, Gothic novels, modern mass culture, critical theory, and migration.</p>
<p>In keeping with the department’s overall mission of providing a solid liberal arts education, <a title="Courses" href="/courses/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">German language courses</span></a> at Berkeley go beyond the teaching of grammar and vocabulary. Learning a foreign language involves learning new forms of expression that are also new ways of thinking. Central goals for the study of German language at Berkeley include the acquisition of communicative competencies, tools for interpretation, and critical awareness of both students’ own native culture(s) and "things foreign."</p>
<p>Our students have ample opportunities to immerse themselves in the language by attending departmental <a href="/events/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">events</span></a> such as the weekly Kaffeeklatsch, Stammtisch, or Film Club, to <a href="/study-abroad/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">study abroad</span></a>, and to apply for awards.</p>
<p>Our program, <a href="/users/?grp=Professors"><span style="text-decoration: underline">faculty</span></a>, <a href="/users/?grp=Lecturers"><span style="text-decoration: underline">instructors</span></a>, and <a href="/users/?grp=Staff"><span style="text-decoration: underline">staff</span></a> encourage students to achieve their individual goals, whether those include pursuing a <a href="/minor/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">minor</span></a>, <a href="/major/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">major</span></a> or <a href="/double-major/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">double major</span></a>, <a href="/honors/">Honors</a>, or <a href="/general-education-breadth-requirement-courses/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">general education</span></a>. The German Undergraduate Program provides students with the language fluency, cultural knowledge, academic experience, and analytical skills necessary to attend <a href="/graduate/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">graduate school</span></a>, to enter the job market, and to be global citizens who are culturally aware and critical thinkers.</p>
<p>Contact us:</p>
<p><a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Nadia Samadi</span></a> (Undergraduate Student Adviser)<br />
Winfried Kudszus (Undergraduate Faculty Adviser)<br />
<a href="/author/euba/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Niko Euba</span></a> (Language Program Coordinator)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="secondary" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
		<aside class="widget widget_pages" id="pages-5">
						<aside id="nav_menu-4" class="widget widget_nav_menu"><h3 class="widget-title">Programs</h3><div class="menu-programs-2-container"><ul id="menu-programs-2" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-5797" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor current-menu-ancestor current-menu-parent current-page-parent current_page_parent current_page_ancestor menu-item-has-children menu-item-5797"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/">Programs</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-5798" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-2578 current_page_item menu-item-5798"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Undergraduate</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5799" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5799"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/graduate/">Graduate</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5801" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-5801"><a href="http://dutch.berkeley.edu/">Dutch Studies</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5802" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-5802"><a href="http://yiddish.berkeley.edu/">Yiddish Studies</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5800" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5800"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/resources/">Resources</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul></div></aside><aside id="chldpgs" class="widget widget_pages"><ul><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/minor/">Minor</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/major/">Major</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/honors/">Honors</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/double-major/">Double Major</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/general-education-breadth-requirement-courses/">General  Education and Breadth Requirements</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li></ul></aside>		</aside>
			</div><!-- #secondary -->	</div><!-- #main .wrapper -->
	<footer id="colophon" class="clear" role="contentinfo" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPFooter">

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3654" class="post-3654 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Double Major</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The Department of German is very supportive of students wishing to pursue a double major. Combining a German Major with a major in another program of study, like Business, Law, International Relations, Film Studies, or Comparative Literature, will give students a competitive advantage in today’s globalized job market. <a href="http://ls.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">The College of Letters &amp; Sciences</span></a> allows a higher unit ceiling to double majors.</p>
<p>The German Department tries to accommodate double majors to facilitate completing and managing the additional work. Students can enroll in upper-division German courses taught in English while they are starting to learn the language. The department also offers intensive language workshops during the summer that allow students to complete a whole year of German in only ten or fifteen weeks. Many <a href="/courses/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">classes</span></a> offered by the department fulfill some of the college's <a href="/general-education-breadth-requirement-courses/">breadth requirements</a>, and half of the courses required for the major may be completed while <a href="/study-abroad/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">studying abroad</span></a>. Additionally, two courses taken in other departments can count toward the German major if those courses concern European topics.</p>
<p>To declare a double major, fill out a <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/planning/schedule-planning/double-majors-and-simultaneous-degrees" target="_blank">double major packet</a> from the <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/planning/schedule-planning/double-majors-and-simultaneous-degrees" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">College of Letters &amp; Science</span></a>. You will need to prepare a four-year plan and get signatures from both departments.</p>
<p>Please consult <a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Nadia Samadi</span></a> (Undergraduate Student Adviser) if you are interested in pursuing a double major, when there are questions about these requirements, and for further information.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3662" class="post-3662 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">General  Education and Breadth Requirements</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The German Department offers a variety of courses that require no knowledge of the German language. If you do not know the language and are interested in learning more about German literature and culture, history and philosophy, or social sciences and international issues, please choose from the classes listed below. (Please note that not all courses are offered each semester; check the <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Schedule of Classes</a> for details).</p>
<p>Please search the <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/seven-course-breadth-requirement" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Berkeley Academic Guide</a> for German courses that fulfill breadth requirements.</p>
<p>Please consult our <a href="/courses/">departmental course listings</a> and the university's <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Schedule of Classes</a> or <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/">CalCentral</a> for further information. Also check listings in <a href="http://dutch.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://yiddish.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Yiddish</a> for information about related breadth requirement courses.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3650" class="post-3650 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Honors</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The German Department encourages all qualifying majors to write an Honors thesis. Ideally, students should start planning to apply to the Honors Program at the end of the junior year. The German Department admits to its Honors Program students who have at least a 3.5 GPA in all upper-division courses taken to fulfill the major requirements, and a 3.3 GPA overall.</p>
<p>Within their senior year, students in the Honors Program are required to complete satisfactorily an Honors thesis under faculty supervision. It is the student's responsibility to ask a faculty member to supervise the thesis. The Honors thesis, which should be at least 35 pages in length, may grow out of any upper-division course, independent study, or directed research, and is evaluated with a letter grade.</p>
<p>Typically, the work on the thesis is spread over two semesters. For the first semester, the student should enroll in the appropriate section of German 199: "Supervised Independent Study" for his or her thesis adviser (2 units; Pass/Fail). In the second semester, the student enrolls in German H196 (4 units (or 6 units in special circumstances and with the approval of the <a href="/author/kfeldman/">undergraduate adviser</a>); letter grade). Those who have completed the thesis will graduate with Honors, High Honors, or Highest Honors in the Major.</p>
<p>Please submit the application for the Honors Program to <a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Nadia Samadi</span></a> (Undergraduate Student Adviser) and consult with her for further information about these requirements.</p>
<p><strong>Funding for Undergraduate Research and Honors Thesis Projects</strong></p>
<p>The Department of German and the university offer various opportunities and funding for undergraduate students of all levels who are interested in research, field-study, or creative projects. Please visit <a href="http://research.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Undergraduate Research at Berkeley</span></a> and <a href="http://surf.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowships</span></a> for more information and application forms.</p>
<p>Prospective students for the Honors program should apply in their junior year to be eligible for summer research funding.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3524" class="post-3524 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Major</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The German Studies Major is designed to lead from the acquisition of competence in written and spoken German through an understanding of the language’s structure and history. The program’s goal is to provide students with a critical understanding of past and contemporary German-speaking society and culture. Students are also trained in advanced study and independent research.</p>
<p>The department offers a variety of <a href="/courses/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">courses</span></a> for the major. Listed below are the requirements for completing a German Studies Major, and a note about related courses outside of the major that may be taken in order to complete all of the requirements. The department’s policy is to maintain a balanced strength between language and literature.</p>
<p>All courses counted toward the major must be taken for a letter grade, and a major GPA of 2.0 must be maintained. Students must fulfill the following requirements.</p>
<p><strong>Lower-Division Requirements</strong></p>
<p>German 1, 2, 3, and 4 or equivalent. If the courses are taken at UC Berkeley, students have to complete each level before proceeding to the next one. Students who have prior knowledge of German but are uncertain as to the appropriate level of instruction they need to continue should contact German Language Program Coordinator <a href="http://german2013.lscrtest.com/author/euba/">Nikolaus Euba</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Upper-Division Requirements</strong></p>
<p>A minimum of ten upper-division courses totaling at least 30 units, at least five courses and 15 units of which must be taken at UC Berkeley. Students must take courses dealing with at least two different centuries, and core course requirements must be satisfied.</p>
<p>The following courses are required:</p>
<ul>
<li>German 100 (core course (3 units))</li>
<li>German 101 (core course (3 units))</li>
<li>German 103 (core course (3 units); only offered in the fall)</li>
<li>3 additional upper-division courses (German 100 or German 101 are a prerequisite for these upper-division courses; must be taught in German)</li>
<li>2 upper-division German courses</li>
<li>2 additional upper-division courses offered by the German Department or 2 upper-division courses related to Germany or Europe offered by an affiliated department</li>
</ul>
<p>If a student has completed at least 15 upper-division units with a grade average of no less than "B," the student has the option to enroll in German 198/199 to study in a group or independently (this course may not be counted toward the 30-unit total).</p>
<p>A major can be declared at any time, but this is usually done when a student is taking German 4. Students may also consider pursuing <a href="/honors/">Honors</a>, a <a href="/double-major/">double major</a>, or a <a href="/minor/">minor</a>.</p>
<p>Please consult <a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Nadia Samadi</span></a> (Undergraduate Student Adviser) when there are questions or doubts about these requirements, or for further information. Please also contact them if you are transferring from another institution and wish to declare the German major.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->

				</h1>
							</div>
				
		<nav id="site-navigation" class="main-navigation" role="navigation" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/SiteNavigationElement">
			<h1 class="menu-toggle">Menu</h1>
			<a class="assistive-text" href="#content" title="Skip to content">Skip to content</a>
			<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="nav-menu"><li id="menu-item-5776" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5776"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/about/">About</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5777" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5777"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/people/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5778" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor menu-item-5778"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/">Programs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5781" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5781"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/news/">News</a></li>

</ul></div>		</nav><!-- #site-navigation -->

				<!-- Custom Header - Start -->
														<!-- Custom Header - End -->

	</header><!-- #masthead -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3522" class="post-3522 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Minor</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The German Studies Minor is designed to provide proficiency in written and spoken German, as well as a thorough acquaintance with German-speaking culture, society, and history. Students are also trained in advanced study and independent research.</p>
<p>The department offers a variety of <a href="/courses/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">courses</span></a> for the minor. Listed below are the requirements for completing a German Studies Minor, and a note about related courses that may be taken in order to complete all of the requirements. The department’s policy is to maintain a balance between language and literature.</p>
<p>All courses counted toward the minor must be taken for a letter grade. Students must fulfill the following requirements.</p>
<p><strong>Lower-Division Requirements</strong></p>
<p>German 1, 2, 3, and 4 or equivalent. If these courses are taken at UC Berkeley, students must complete each level before proceeding to the next one. Students who have prior knowledge of German but are uncertain as to the appropriate level of instruction they need to continue should contact the German Language Program Coordinator, <a href="/author/euba/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Nikolaus Euba</span></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Upper-Division Requirements</strong></p>
<p>A minimum of five upper-division courses totaling at least 15 units, at least three courses and nine units of which must be taken at Berkeley. Students must enroll in at least two courses in which knowledge of German is required. One of the five courses should deal with broader socio-cultural, historical issues. A letter grade of "C" or better is required for each upper-division course applied to the minor.</p>
<p>The following courses are required:</p>
<ul>
<li>German 100 (core course (3 units))</li>
<li>German 101 (core course (3 units))</li>
<li>German 103 (core course (3 units); only offered in the fall)</li>
<li>1 upper-division German course (in English or German)</li>
<li>1 upper-division course (texts in English, German, Dutch, or Yiddish literature and culture) offered by the German Department or 1 upper-division course related to Germany or Europe offered by an affiliated department</li>
</ul>
<p>If a student has completed at least 15 upper-division units with a grade average of no less than "B," the student has the option to enroll in German 198/199 to study in a group or independently (this course may not be counted toward the 15-unit total).</p>
<p>A minor does not need to be formally declared; yet during the last semester of a student’s minor program, the student must file a petition to declare the minor with the Undergraduate Adviser, <a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Nadia Samadi</span></a>. Students may also consider pursuing a <a href="/major/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">major</span></a>, <a href="/honors/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Honors</span></a>, or a <a href="/double-major/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">double major</span></a>.</p>
<p>Please consult <a href="/author/nsamadi/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Nadia Samadi</span></a> for further information before registering for courses to be applied to the minor, or when there are questions or doubts about these requirements.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

			<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="nav-menu"><li id="menu-item-5776" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5776"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/about/">About</a></li>

	</header><!-- #masthead -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3664" class="post-3664 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Study Abroad</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>One of the great benefits of pursuing a degree in German is the option to study abroad.</p>
<p>Students in the German Department have a variety of opportunities to study abroad: the <a href="/education-abroad-program-uceap/">Education Abroad Program</a> (UCEAP), summer language courses in <a href="http://www.fubis.org/" target="_blank">Berlin</a> (FUBiS) and <a href="http://w3-n.hm.edu/en/course_offerings/mssas/munichsummerschool_uebersicht.en.html" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Munich</span></a>, and several <a href="http://german2013.lscrtest.com/files/2014/04/Kurzbeschreibungen-regulärer-DAAD-Programme-Nordamerika.pdf" target="_blank">programs</a> of the <a href="https://daad.org/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">German Academic Exchange Service</span></a> (DAAD). The programs supported by Berkeley allow students to keep their financial aid and transfer their course credits from Germany.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
