	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3856" class="post-3856 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">A Letter from Scott McElhinney</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><em><a style="color: #ff0000" href="mailto:scottmc@berkeley.edu" target="_blank">Scott McElhinney</a> is our adviser for the German Study Abroad Program</em></p>
<div class="entry-content cf" style="color: #333333">
<p>Dear Student:</p>
<p>Why Study in Germany? To learn all about this great nation and its fascinating culture--its history, music, intellectuals, scientists, sports, politics, reunification, environmentalism, food, beer, wine, etc. And of course, for its rich language and literature.</p>
<p>While many Germans speak English, very few Americans know German well enough to carry on a conversation, let alone carry out serious academic pursuits. UCEAP gives you opportunities to do both. And what’s unique and helpful about studying abroad via UCEAP (UC’s very own program) is that all your financial aid goes with you, and your courses and grades transfer back automatically to your Cal transcript.</p>
<p>Plus, Germany is one of the least expensive UCEAP programs in Western Europe and you can apply for scholarships to help you pay for it. So take a look at these brief descriptions of the various options in Germany and see which one fits your interests. Then go to the Berkeley Study Abroad <a style="color: #ff0000" title="UCB Study Abroad Site" href="http://studyabroad.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">website</a> for all the details and an application checklist.</p>
<p>The <b>International Summer School at Free University in Berlin</b> (Freie Universität Berlin) allows students with any level of German to enroll in two courses--either two language courses, two subject matter courses (mostly taught in English), or one of each. This option is open to sophomores through graduate students with a GPA of 2.8. The application deadline is in early February.</p>
<p>Another summer option in Germany is UCEAP’s new "<b>Engineering for Sustainability</b>"<b> </b>program at the <strong>University of Applied Sciences</strong><b> in Munich</b>. Take project-based engineering courses that include lab experiments and simulations and visits to global companies headquartered in Munich. Courses are geared toward mechanical, automotive, electrical, industrial, and environmental engineering, plus entrepreneurship and German language. Open to Juniors and Seniors, this option requires no prior German. 2.85 minimum GPA. Application deadline is in early January.</p>
<p>Don’t know a word of German? Studied 1-3 semesters of German already? Then consider the <b>Berlin European Studies (BEST) program at Free University in Berlin</b>. You’ll focus on courses taught in English about Berlin, Germany, and the European Union, plus take a German language course as well. No prior German is required (and no more than German 3 is allowed). A GPA of 2.85 is required; sophomores through seniors may participate. You can live in a homestay or in a studio apartment in the same building with other UC or American students. Apply in early December for fall; early April for spring.</p>
<p>So you’d like to do an old-fashioned junior year abroad in Germany? No problem! Semesters are available, too, and senior year works for many students as well. You can study at the Technical, Free, or Humboldt universities in Berlin.</p>
<p>If you want to do this "immersion" option, you can either take up through German 4 by the end of the spring semester before you want to go with UCEAP for the year or fall semester, or you can take up through German 2 or 3 by the end of the spring semester before you want to go and participate in the Pre-Intensive Language Program (pre-ILP) in July in Berlin to learn the rest of second year German. Then you’ll be ready to enter the Intensive Language Program (ILP) that all participants must take before starting regular courses alongside the German students beginning in October.</p>
<p>For spring semester, students need to complete at least German 3 by the end of the fall semester prior to departure, then attend a shorter pre-ILP in January in Berlin to complete German 4, then stay for the ILP that leads up to the beginning of regular courses in April.</p>
<p>If you will have completed German 4 before departure, then you don’t need to participate in the pre-ILP; if you will have completed an upper division course taught in German, then you can skip the ILP as well. But you’re welcome to participate in the pre-ILP and/or ILP if you wish.</p>
<p>At first, taking regular courses taught in German might seem daunting, but gradually your German skills will improve sufficiently for you to do well in your classes. Every year, many UC students accomplish this and by the end of the semester or year are quite proficient at a high academic level. You can do it, too! This can serve you well if you go on to graduate school and want to do research in German-speaking areas, or if you want to do business of any kind in Germany or other parts of the world.</p>
<p>Spending a full year in Germany allows your German skills to develop to a very high degree, plus it enables you to get to know the country and culture more deeply. You’re more likely to make close friendships by staying for a year, as well.</p>
<p>If you can’t participate for an entire year, it’s still possible to do half a year of regular coursework. Fall semester is problematic unless you are a graduating senior, because it continues on until March, so other students would encounter the problem of missing spring semester back at Cal. The spring semester would be a better option for students who don’t want to miss two semesters here.</p>
<p>All fall and year immersion options have an early January application deadline. All spring options have an early April application deadline.</p>
<p>For all of these immersion options, junior status (56 units including AP) and a GPA of 2.85 overall and in your German language courses are required.</p>
<p>Like most students, you’ll probably live in a WG (<em>Wohngemeinschaft</em>), which is an apartment shared with German students. That way you can practice the German you will have worked so hard to learn.</p>
<p>So no matter what your class level, language level, or major, you’ll find a UCEAP option that can help you to get first-hand experience in Germany. What are you waiting for? Just click onto the UCEAP <a style="color: #ff0000" title="UCB Study Abroad Site" href="http://eap.ucop.edu/Pages/index-new.html" target="_blank">website</a> to see photos, read student comments, and to get additional information. Go for it!</p>
<p>Please contact <a href="mailto:scottmc@berkeley.edu" target="_blank">me</a> for all questions about UC’s Education Abroad Program.</p>
<p>-Scott McElhinney, UC Berkeley Study Abroad Adviser for Germany</p>
</div>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-3666" class="post-3666 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Education Abroad Program</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The <a href="http://studyabroad.berkeley.edu/eap" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Education Abroad Program</span></a> at UC Berkeley (UCEAP) offers students the opportunity to study abroad while keeping their financial aid and being able to automatically transfer their courses and grades back to Berkeley. Studying in Germany is one of the least expensive UCEAP programs in Western Europe, and students can apply for additional scholarships.</p>
<p>Students can choose to study abroad for a full year, for just one semester (spring semester being the better option), or during the summer. This <a href="/a-letter-from-scott-mcelhinney/"><span style="text-decoration: underline">letter</span></a> from German Study Abroad Program Adviser Scott McElhinney provides more information about UCEAP. Please also check the <a href="http://studyabroad.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Berkeley Study Abroad website</span></a> for all the details and an application checklist. Contact <a href="mailto:scottmc@berkeley.edu" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Scott McElhinney</span></a> if you have further questions.</p>
<p><strong>Studying Abroad for a Semester or a Full Year</strong></p>
<p>If you are interested in studying a full semester in Germany, consider the <a href="http://www.fu-berlin.de/en/sites/fubest/" target="_blank">Berlin European Studies Program (BEST)</a> at the <a href="http://www.fu-berlin.de/en/" target="_blank">Freie Universität Berlin</a>. The program offers courses taught in English about Germany and the European Union, and no prior German is required (no competency higher than German 3 is allowed). Applications are due in early December for fall and early April for spring.</p>
<p>Studying a semester or year abroad in Germany is also possible outside of the BEST program  at Freie Universität Berlin, as well as at <a href="http://www.tu-berlin.de/" target="_blank">Technische Universität Berlin</a> and <a href="https://www.hu-berlin.de/" target="_blank">Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin.</a> All fall and year-long immersion options have an early January application deadline. All spring options have an early April application deadline. For all of these immersion options, junior status (56 units including AP) and a GPA of 2.85 overall and in German language courses are required.</p>
<p><strong>Studying Abroad during the Summer</strong></p>
<p>The UCEAP/FUBiS program at the Freie Universität International Summer University in Berlin allows students with any level of German (from none to advanced) to enroll in one or two language and subject matter courses. For more information, please see the <a href="http://www.fubis.org/" target="_blank">FUBiS</a> and <a href="http://eap.ucop.edu/OurPrograms/germany/Pages/free_univ_summer.aspx" target="_blank">UCEAP</a> websites. This option is open to sophomores through graduate students with a GPA of 2.8. The application deadline is in early February.</p>
<p>Students attending FUBiS individually or through UCEAP are eligible to apply for a Max Kade Travel Stipend of $1000 in support of their travel, made possible by generous support from the Max Kade Foundation. Applications are due to <a href="/author/nsamadi/">Nadia Samadi</a> (Undergraduate Services) at the end of February each year. Please contact Nadia for the application form.</p>
<p>Another summer study abroad option in Germany is UCEAP’s <a href="http://eap.ucop.edu/OurPrograms/germany/Pages/engineering_sustainability_munich_u_applied_science.aspx" target="_blank">Engineering for Sustainability Program</a> at the <a href="http://www.hm.edu/en/index.en.html" target="_blank">University of Applied Sciences in Munich</a>. Students take project-based engineering courses that include lab experiments and simulations, and participants visit global companies headquartered in Munich. Courses are geared toward mechanical, automotive, electrical, industrial, and environmental engineering, as well as entrepreneurship and German language. Open to juniors and seniors, this option requires no prior German. Interested students should have a minimum 2.85 GPA. The application deadline is in early January.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		<footer class="entry-meta">
					</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="secondary" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
		<aside class="widget widget_pages" id="pages-5">
						<aside id="nav_menu-4" class="widget widget_nav_menu"><h3 class="widget-title">Programs</h3><div class="menu-programs-2-container"><ul id="menu-programs-2" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-5797" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor menu-item-has-children menu-item-5797"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/">Programs</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-5798" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor menu-item-5798"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Undergraduate</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5799" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5799"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/graduate/">Graduate</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5801" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-5801"><a href="http://dutch.berkeley.edu/">Dutch Studies</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5802" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-5802"><a href="http://yiddish.berkeley.edu/">Yiddish Studies</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-5800" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5800"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/resources/">Resources</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul></div></aside><aside id="pcpgs" class="widget widget_pages"><ul><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/study-abroad/a-letter-from-scott-mcelhinney/">A Letter from Scott McElhinney</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/study-abroad/education-abroad-program-uceap/">Education Abroad Program</a></li></ul></aside><aside id="pcpgs" class="widget widget_pages"><ul><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/minor/">Minor</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/major/">Major</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/honors/">Honors</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/double-major/">Double Major</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/general-education-breadth-requirement-courses/">General  Education and Breadth Requirements</a></li><li class="page_item"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li></ul></aside>		</aside>
			</div><!-- #secondary -->	</div><!-- #main .wrapper -->
	<footer id="colophon" class="clear" role="contentinfo" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPFooter">
	
						<div id="footer-widgets" class="widget-area three" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPSideBar">

	<article id="post-5359" class="post-5359 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Prospective Student Visit Day: Presentation by Paul Reitter, Mar 15-16, 2015</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/prospective-student-visit-day-presentation-by-paul-reitter-mar-15-16-2015/" title="9:00 am" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-03-16T09:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">March 16, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Followed by discussion. <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=86595&amp;date=2015-03-16" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">

			!function(a,b,c){function d(a){var b,c,d,e,f=String.fromCharCode;if(!k||!k.fillText)return!1;switch(k.clearRect(0,0,j.width,j.height),k.textBaseline="top",k.font="600 32px Arial",a){case"flag":return k.fillText(f(55356,56826,55356,56819),0,0),!(j.toDataURL().length<3e3)&&(k.clearRect(0,0,j.width,j.height),k.fillText(f(55356,57331,65039,8205,55356,57096),0,0),b=j.toDataURL(),k.clearRect(0,0,j.width,j.height),k.fillText(f(55356,57331,55356,57096),0,0),c=j.toDataURL(),b!==c);case"emoji4":return k.fillText(f(55357,56425,55356,57341,8205,55357,56507),0,0),d=j.toDataURL(),k.clearRect(0,0,j.width,j.height),k.fillText(f(55357,56425,55356,57341,55357,56507),0,0),e=j.toDataURL(),d!==e}return!1}function e(a){var c=b.createElement("script");c.src=a,c.defer=c.type="text/javascript",b.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(c)}var f,g,h,i,j=b.createElement("canvas"),k=j.getContext&&j.getContext("2d");for(i=Array("flag","emoji4"),c.supports={everything:!0,everythingExceptFlag:!0},h=0;h<i.length;h++)c.supports[i[h]]=d(i[h]),c.supports.everything=c.supports.everything&&c.supports[i[h]],"flag"!==i[h]&&(c.supports.everythingExceptFlag=c.supports.everythingExceptFlag&&c.supports[i[h]]);c.supports.everythingExceptFlag=c.supports.everythingExceptFlag&&!c.supports.flag,c.DOMReady=!1,c.readyCallback=function(){c.DOMReady=!0},c.supports.everything||(g=function(){c.readyCallback()},b.addEventListener?(b.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded",g,!1),a.addEventListener("load",g,!1)):(a.attachEvent("onload",g),b.attachEvent("onreadystatechange",function(){"complete"===b.readyState&&c.readyCallback()})),f=c.source||{},f.concatemoji?e(f.concatemoji):f.wpemoji&&f.twemoji&&(e(f.twemoji),e(f.wpemoji)))}(window,document,window._wpemojiSettings);
		</script>

	<article id="post-2662" class="post-2662 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Publication for Grad Student Dobryden</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/publication-for-grad-student-dobryden/" title="1:09 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2010-05-31T13:09:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2010</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Paul Dobryden published “Good Germans, Humane Automobiles: Redeeming Technological Modernity—In Those Days” in <em>Film and History</em> 40.1 (Spring 2010).</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/publication-for-grad-student-dobryden/" title="1:09 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2010-05-31T13:09:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2010</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<article id="post-2787" class="post-2787 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Rauch and Grad Students Publish Article</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/rauch-and-grad-students-publish-article/" title="2:28 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:28:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Irmengard Rauch and co-authors Julisa Edwards, Justin Farwell, Carolyn Hawkshaw, MaryEllen LeBlanc, Chris Little, Stephanie Peltner, Tim Price, Michael St. Clair, Peter Woods published “BAG XI: Toward Human:Canine Communication” in “The Interdisciplinary Journal for Germanic Linguistics and Semiotic Analysis” vol. 16,2 (2011), pages 203-254.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/rauch-and-grad-students-publish-article/" title="2:28 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2012-05-31T14:28:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2012</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-418" class="post-418 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Graduate Placement</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>The department has an outstanding placement record. Over the last decade, PhDs in German accepted tenure-track or long-term positions at the following institutions: The University of Arizona, Brigham Young University, Georgetown University, University of Illinois at Chicago, Southern Illinois University, Indiana University/Purdue University, University of Maryland, McGill University in Montreal, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Ohio State University, University of Rochester, University of Virginia, University of Washington at Seattle, and Washington University in St. Louis.</p>
<p>The department is committed to helping students secure appointments in academia. This effort includes a workshop on all aspects of the academic job market early in each fall semester, reviewing of curriculum vitae and letters of application, mock interviews, and follow-up advising.</p>
<p><strong>Placements by Year </strong>(since 2010)</p>
<p>2015-16</p>
<p>Born, Erik [Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship at the Society for the Humanities, Cornell University]<br />
Dobryden, Paul [Asst. Prof., University of Virginia]<br />
Ellis, Robin [Visiting Asst. Prof. Davidson College]<br />
Mušanović, Emina [Asst. Prof., Linfield College]</p>
<p>2014-15</p>
<p>Allred, Mason [Historian and Editor, The Joseph Smith Papers]<br />
<a href="http://lsa.umich.edu/german/people/faculty/dickins.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dickinson, Kristin</a> [Asst. Prof., University of Michigan]<br />
Gordon, Kevin A. [Instructional Designer, UCLA Extension]</p>
<p>2013-14</p>
<p><a href="http://www.zfl-berlin.org/personenliste-detail/items/almog.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Almog, Yael</a> [Asst. Prof., Center of Literary and Cultural Research in Berlin (ZfL)]<br />
Etzler, Melissa [Instructor, Butler University]<br />
<a href="http://www.hws.edu/academics/german/facultyProfile.aspx?facultyID=1228">Manthripragada, Ashwin</a> [Visiting Asst. Prof., Hobart and William Smith Colleges]</p>
<p>2012-13</p>
<p><a href="http://german.wustl.edu/people/kurt-beals" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Beals, Kurt</a> [Asst. Prof., Washington University in St. Louis]<br />
Haubenreich, Jacob [Asst. Prof., Southern Illinois University]<br />
<a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/instructor/jkooiker" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Kooiker, Jason</a> [Lecturer, Stanford Language Center]</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 16px;">2011-12</span></p>
<p><a href="http://www.morris.umn.edu/academics/german/faculty/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dewey, Tonya</a> [Asst. Prof., University of Minnesota, Morris]<br />
Kolar, Meredith [Lecturer, University of Zürich]<br />
<a href="http://layne.web.unc.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Layne, Priscilla</a> [Asst. Prof., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]<br />
Price, Timothy [Research Fellow, University Frankfurt, Germany]<br />
St. Clair, Michael [Lecturer, UC Berkeley]</p>
<p>2010-11</p>
<p><a href="http://german.arizona.edu/people/david-gramling" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Gramling, David</a> [Asst. Prof., The University of Arizona]<br />
<a href="http://trop.web.unc.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Trop, Gabriel</a> [Asst. Prof., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	<header id="masthead" class="site-header" role="banner">
					<div class="site-branding" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPHeader">
				<h1 class="site-title">
					<a href="http://berkeley.edu/index.html" class="tilt" title="UC Berkeley" style="float:left; width: 15.5%; min-width: 10rem; margin: 1.1% 0 0 7.8%;">

			<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="nav-menu"><li id="menu-item-5776" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5776"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/about/">About</a></li>

	</header><!-- #masthead -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5181" class="post-5181 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Seminar: Baroque Orientalism, Sep 5-Oct 3, 2014</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-2/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-12T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 12, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>In the 17th-century, the Thirty Years' War and wars with the Turks, recurring at multiple fronts across Eastern and Central Europe, were formative forces. Military battles went along with the drawing of ideological and confessional boundaries, which continue to take effect in today's Europe. Against this backdrop, the seminar aims <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=79528&amp;date=2014-09-12" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5188" class="post-5188 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Seminar: Baroque Orientalism, Sep 5-Oct 3, 2014</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-3/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-19T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 19, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>In the 17th-century, the Thirty Years' War and wars with the Turks, recurring at multiple fronts across Eastern and Central Europe, were formative forces. Military battles went along with the drawing of ideological and confessional boundaries, which continue to take effect in today's Europe. Against this backdrop, the seminar aims <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=79528&amp;date=2014-09-19" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-3/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-19T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 19, 2014</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

				<nav class="nav-single">
					<h3 class="assistive-text">Post navigation</h3>

					<span class="nav-next"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/conference-zweig-in-the-world-sep-24/" rel="next">Conference: &quot;Zweig in the World&quot;, Sep 24 <span class="meta-nav">&raquo;</span></a></span>

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">

		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5196" class="post-5196 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Seminar: Baroque Orientalism, Sep 5-Oct 3, 2014</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-4/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-26T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 26, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>In the 17th-century, the Thirty Years' War and wars with the Turks, recurring at multiple fronts across Eastern and Central Europe, were formative forces. Military battles went along with the drawing of ideological and confessional boundaries, which continue to take effect in today's Europe. Against this backdrop, the seminar aims <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=79528&amp;date=2014-09-26" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-4/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-26T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 26, 2014</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="main" class="wrapper">
	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-5203" class="post-5203 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Seminar: Baroque Orientalism, Sep 5-Oct 3, 2014</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-5/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-10-03T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">October 3, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>In the 17th-century, the Thirty Years' War and wars with the Turks, recurring at multiple fronts across Eastern and Central Europe, were formative forces. Military battles went along with the drawing of ideological and confessional boundaries, which continue to take effect in today's Europe. Against this backdrop, the seminar aims <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=79528&amp;date=2014-10-03" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014-5/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-10-03T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">October 3, 2014</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

				<nav class="nav-single">
					<h3 class="assistive-text">Post navigation</h3>

					<span class="nav-next"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/workshop-allegory-as-production-of-evidence-albrecht-koschorke-and-niklaus-largier-oct-5/" rel="next">Workshop: Allegory as Production of Evidence (Albrecht Koschorke and Niklaus Largier), Oct 5 <span class="meta-nav">&raquo;</span></a></span>
				</nav><!-- .nav-single -->

	<article id="post-5077" class="post-5077 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Seminar: Baroque Orientalism, Sep 5-Oct 3, 2014</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-05T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 5, 2014</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>In the 17th-century, the Thirty Years' War and wars with the Turks, recurring at multiple fronts across Eastern and Central Europe, were formative forces. Military battles went along with the drawing of ideological and confessional boundaries, which continue to take effect in today's Europe. Against this backdrop, the seminar aims <a href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/german.html?event_ID=79528&amp;date=2014-09-05" target="_self" id="rssmi_more"> ...read more</a></p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/seminar-baroque-orientalism-sep-5-oct-3-2014/" title="1:00 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2014-09-05T13:00:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">September 5, 2014</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/admin/" title="View all posts by WordPress Administrator" rel="author" itemprop="url">WordPress Administrator</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

	<div id="primary" class="site-content">
		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-498" class="post-498 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Spring Courses</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><b><i>COURSE DESCRIPTIONS- SPRING 2018</i></b></p>
<p><em><strong>Language Courses:</strong></em></p>
<p>German 1 (5) <em><strong>Elementary German I.</strong></em> Euba in charge.<br />
Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet two or five times a week. All four foreign language skills (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) are addressed to help students acquire communicative competence in the German language while being sensitized to the links between language and culture. German 1 is for students with no prior knowledge of German.</p>
<p>German 2 (5) <em><strong>Elementary German II.</strong></em> Euba in charge.<br />
Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet five times a week. In German 2, students will continue to develop communicative competence in the German language and expand their sensitivity toward the relationship between language and culture. While all language skills will be addressed, additional emphasis will be on the various styles of written and spoken German. Prerequisite: German 1 or equivalent.</p>
<p>German 3 (5) <em><strong>Intermediate German I.</strong></em> Topics in German Language and Cultural History. Euba in charge.<br />
Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet five times a week. While continuing to expand students’ communicative competence in German, this content-driven course will provide insights into postwar German history and cultural trends. The primary focus will be on the development of literacy skills (critical reading and writing), vocabulary expansion, and a thorough review of structural concepts. Students will be guided toward expressing themselves on more abstract topics, such as language and power in society, multiculturalism, rebellion and protest, and social justice, and toward drawing connections between texts and contexts by using a variety of text genres (journalistic, historical, short story, poetry, drama, advertising, film).</p>
<p>German 4 (5)<em> <strong>Intermediate German II.</strong></em> Topics in German Language and Culture. Euba in charge.<br />
Fall/Spring. Five units; classes meet five times a week. In this fourth-semester German language course, students work on strengthening their interpretative abilities as well as their written and oral forms of expression. While continuing the development of communicative competence and literacy skills, students will discuss a variety of texts and films and try to find innovative ways in which to engage with familiar presuppositions about who we are, about what determines our values and actions, and about the function and power of language.</p>
<p><em><strong>German R5B- Reading and Composition Courses (4 units):</strong></em><br />
Readings and discussions in English. Fulfills the second half of the university’s Reading &amp; Composition Requirement (equivalent to English 1B, Comp. Lit. 1B, etc.).<strong><br />
</strong><br />
German R5B Section 1: Staff<br />
TBA</p>
<p>German R5B Section 2: Staff<br />
TBA</p>
<p>German R5B Section 3: Staff<br />
TBA</p>
<p>German R5B Section 4: Staff<br />
TBA</p>
<p>German R5B Section 5: Staff<br />
TBA</p>
<p><em><strong>Courses Taught in German:</strong></em></p>
<p>German 100 (3) <em><strong>Introduction to Reading Culture.</strong></em> Dewulf<br />
This course is intended to acquaint students with selected works from German cultural history and to familiarize them with various methods of interpretation and analysis. Required for all German majors. Fulfills the Letters &amp; Science requirement in Arts and Literature or International Studies. Taught in German. Students with native fluency in German are not eligible to enroll. Prerequisite: German 4.</p>
<p>German 101 (3) <em><strong>Advanced German Conversation, Composition, and Style.</strong> </em>Staff<br />
Focusing on five central themes, this advanced-level language course will help students improve and expand on spoken and written language functions utilizing a variety of works from different genres in journalism, broadcasting, literature, fine arts, and cinema. The final goal is to enable students to participate in the academic discourse (written and spoken) to a linguistic and stylistic level appropriate for advanced students of German in upper division courses. Fulfills the Letters &amp; Science breadth requirement in Arts and Literature or International Studies. Taught in German. Students with native fluency in German are not eligible to enroll. Prerequisite: German 4.</p>
<p>German 102A (3) <em><strong>Advanced Language Practice: German Performance.</strong></em> N. Euba<br />
The analysis, discussion, adaptation and public performance of primarily poetic texts will advance students' language and interpersonal competencies while providing unique access to a significant dimension of German popular culture as well as innovative approaches to reading and interpreting poetry. Students enrolled need to be available for some  afternoon/evening performances <span class="aBn" tabindex="0" data-term="goog_1959323878"><span class="aQJ">April 18 through 21, 2018</span></span>.</p>
<p>German 103 (3) <em><strong>Introduction to German Linguistics. </strong></em>T. Shannon<br />
This course is designed to provide students with an overview of the major subfields of linguistics as they apply to the German language. It also serves as the gateway course for the further study of German linguistics at the undergraduate level. The first part of the course will focus on the synchronic description of contemporary German. The second part of the course will concern itself with variation in German. There are no prerequisites for this class and no prior experience with linguistics is presupposed. However, an advanced knowledge of German (at least German 4 level) is expected.</p>
<p>German 108 (3) <em><strong>Literary Translation.</strong> </em>W. Kudszus<br />
Our focus will be the practice and theory of literary translation, primarily from German to English. Following their particular interests, participants will choose a text or a constellation of texts for their individual semester projects. These projects will be introduced in an oral presentation (20-25 minutes) and develop into a semester paper, which typically will involve the translation of a text and reflections on your own translational stance.</p>
<p>German 152 (3) <em><strong>Modern Literature</strong>.</em> W. Kudszus<br />
Some of the most influential and thought-provoking literary works of the wider 20th century will be among our readings, including texts by Friedrich Nietzsche, Sigmund Freud, Rainer Maria Rilke, Franz Kafka, Else Lasker-Schüler, Elfriede Jelinek, and Herta Müller. In light of these texts, we will explore questions of identity, madness, and creativity. Readings in German. Lectures in German and English. Discussions and course work in English and/or German.</p>
<p><em><strong>Courses Taught in English:</strong></em></p>
<p>German 24 (1) <em><strong>Freshman Seminar.</strong></em> K. Feldman<br />
"Germany Today".<b>  </b>This FSS will introduce students to the country of Germany--its political system, social issues, and significant cultural elements. We will discuss political parties, the election system, Angela Merkel, Turkish-German and migration issues, arts and literature, and more. No knowledge of the German language is required for this course.</p>
<p>German C25 (4)- <em><strong>Max, Nietzsche, Freud.</strong></em> K. Feldman<br />
We will explore the ways in which Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud--three of the most important thinkers in modern Western thought--can be read as responding to the Enlightenment and its notions of reason and progress. We will consider how each remakes a scientific understanding of truth, knowledge, and subjectivity, such that rationality, logic, and the powers of human cognition are shown to be distorted, limited, and subject to forces outside our individual control. All lectures and readings in English.</p>
<p>German 160B (4) <em><strong>Fascism and Propaganda.</strong></em> I. Richter<br />
This course will explore methods, effects and the history of propaganda using the example of National Socialism (1933-1945) and will focus on the relationship between politics, propaganda and public opinion. It will highlight practices of persuasion and manipulation and attempts to shape perceptions, and direct behavior to achieve responses intended by the National Socialists. We will discuss the role that propaganda played in the National Socialists’ rise to power. Central institutions, organizational structures and actors will be introduced as well as practices and media such as films, newspapers, posters, exhibitions, photos, commemoration days and speeches. Besides the methods and intended effects, we will also explore sources which provide insights into reactions of the public to the major themes and into the reception of campaigns by the State.</p>
<p><em><strong>Graduate Courses:</strong></em></p>
<p>German 201D (4) <strong><em>19th Century. </em></strong>C. Tang<br />
This course studies the main literary forms and aesthetic paradigms between two epochal thresholds - “around 1800” and “around 1900”. We will read exemplary nineteenth-century texts in light of current scholarship. Authors include Novalis, Kleist, Goethe, Büchner, Heine, Grillparzer, Sacher-Masoch, Wagner, Stifter, Raabe, and Hofmannsthal.</p>
<p>German 214 (4) Room Share with Critical Theory (TBA) <em><strong>Studies in the 20th Century</strong><strong>.</strong></em> D. Gokturk<br />
"Media, Ecology, Migration". This seminar will read theories of old and new media through the lens of two conceptual frameworks environmental criticism and migration studies. Tracing the effects of movement and stillness, interaction and connectivity from early cinema to social media and new forms of data visualizations, participants will develop their own research projects and methodologies by relating questions arising from theory to practice. Drawing on seminal literary and theoretical readings as well as film and multimedia examples, the seminar will test methodologies of critical digital humanities and urban studies, probing interfaces between social sciences and the humanities.  <strong><em>NOTE: This class also meets on Thursday from<br />
</em></strong><strong><em>1-3pm in 282 Dwinelle Hall for film screenings!</em></strong></p>
<p>German 256/Comp. Lit. 250 (4) <em><b>Problems in Literary Theory.</b></em> N. Largier<br />
"Imagination, Fantasy, 'Einbildungskraft'". In this seminar we will discuss the significance of the notions and concepts of the imagination in philosophical and literary traditions. We will start with a discussion of basic texts by Plato and Aristotle; move on to the treatment of the imagination in classical rhetoric; and focus on four key areas where imagination, fantasy, and 'Einbildungskraft' play a significant role: the so-called mystical tradition up to Jacob Böhme; Baroque cultures of the imagination; poetic imagination in the 18th and 19th centuries; and 20th century philosophical approaches. The reading list will include texts by Plato, Aristotle, Quintilian, Ignatius of Loyola, Lohenstein, Böhme, Malebranche, Kant, Addison, Goethe, Moritz, Flaubert, Sartre, and Foucault.</p>
<p>German 263C (4)<em> <strong>Poetry and Thought</strong>.</em> K. Feldman<br />
This graduate seminar will investigate various disputes at the intersection of philosophy and literary theory that arose with respect to poetry and particular poems. We will begin with a short look at 18th-century disputes between Gottsched and Bodmer/Breitinger; and an examination of the convergence of philosophical and poetic thought in Hölderlin, Schelling and Hegel. Turning to the 20th century, we will look at an exchange between Heidegger, Emil Staiger and Leo Spitzer concerning Mörike's "Auf eine Lampe"; at serial analyses of later works of Hölderlin by Heidegger, Adorno and de Man.</p>
<p>German 276 (4) <strong><em>Old High German.</em></strong> I. Rauch<br />
Reading of poetic and prose texts in Old High German; passages selected to represent a broad scope of chronology, geography, and genre in eighth- to eleventh-century German. Cultural dynamics of the Old High German period. The synchronic and diachronic study of phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics and pragmatics; linguistic method. Particular emphasis is placed on the structure of the several principal dialects of Old High German. No prerequisites.</p>
<p>German 280 (4) <em><strong>North Sea Germanic.</strong></em> T. Shannon<br />
Readings and discussion of poetic and prose texts in the Ingwaeonic languages (broadly construed) not covered elsewhere: Old Low Franconian, Middle Dutch, Old Frisian, Middle Low German.</p>
<p><em><strong>Dutch Courses:</strong></em></p>
<p>Dutch 1 (5)<em><strong> Elementary Dutch.</strong></em> I. Van Der Hoeven<br />
In this beginner’s course, students will familiarize themselves with the basics of Dutch: sounds and spelling, vocabulary, and grammar. Weekly themes form the basis of in-class conversations and write-ups. By the end of the semester, students will be able to express themselves in speaking and in writing about a variety of topics, including introducing yourself, time, living, studying, traveling, and talking about present and past situations.</p>
<p>Dutch 2 (5) <em><strong>Elementary Dutch.</strong></em> I. Van Der Hoeven<br />
Dutch language course for beginners expanding on Dutch 1. The focus of the course is on acquiring basic communicative competence in the language. That is, developing the ability to appropriately use the language (spoken as well as written) in authentic situations.</p>
<p>Dutch 100 (3) <b><em>Dutch for Reading and Translation Knowledge.</em> </b>I. Van Der Hoeven<br />
This is a two-track course, designed for 1) research scholars/graduate students who need to learn how to translate Dutch texts in their area of expertise, and 2) Dutch Studies majors and minors who are interested in the professional field of translation (Dutch to English). While some knowledge of Dutch and/or German is required, a Dutch 1 class prior to this class is a prerequisite.</p>
<p>Dutch C164  (4) <strong><em>The Indonesian Connection</em>.  </strong>J. Dewulf<br />
Literature and Film about the Dutch colonial history of Indonesia. Taught in English.</p>
<p><em><strong>Yiddish Courses:</strong></em></p>
<p>Yiddish 102 (5) <b>I<em>ntermediate Yiddish. </em></b>Y. Chaver<br />
Further intensive study of Yiddish for advanced students, building on the foundation established in Yiddish 101; or equivalent knowledge.  Advanced grammar and introduction to reading original texts as well as aspects of Yiddish culture.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

		<div id="content" role="main">
												
	<article id="post-500" class="post-500 page type-page status-publish hentry" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Summer Courses</h1>
			</header>
					
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<div style="text-align: left;">
<p><strong>Intensive German Courses in the Summer<br />
</strong></p>
<p>Embark on an exciting summer journey: Learning German will open up astonishing new cultural vistas, enable you to communicate with 120 million people in several European countries, and expose you to the world of great thinkers such as Nietzsche, Kafka, and Freud. Among the multiple personal, academic, and professional benefits of a foreign language-learning experience is the fact that graduate and law schools in the US are keen on admitting students with advanced knowledge of a foreign language. UC Berkeley offers a variety of German courses and intensive workshops on the Berkeley campus and a workshop for beginners in Berlin.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Summer Abroad in the Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg<br />
</strong></p>
<p>"Introduce yourself to the cultural and political identity of the Low Countries: the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, three contrasting monarchies in the heart of Europe. The course begins in Amsterdam, the world’s most liberal city, from where we explore the Netherlands. After spending two weeks in the Netherlands, we travel to Europe’s capital Brussels, where we join the celebrations of Belgium’s Independence Day. From Brussels, we continue to Luxembourg, one of the smallest but most international countries in Europe. We then move to Flanders, Belgium’s Dutch-speaking region, where we first stay in the city of Ostend, beautifully located at the North Sea coast. We end our course in Louvain, one of Europe’s oldest university towns founded in the Middle Ages. On our way, we trace important cultural, historical and political developments in European history and culture from medieval Flanders, the Dutch Golden Age, World War I and II up to the contemporary multilingual, social and European identity of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg as founding members of the European Union. Daily fieldtrips take us to The Hague, Utrecht, Bruges, Antwerp, Ghent, Ypres, Bastogne, the Frisian Islands, Cassel in French Flanders and many other places. Guided visits to the Dutch House of Representatives and the European Parliament in Brussels are also included." For more information, please see Berkeley's <a href="http://studyabroad.berkeley.edu/berkeleyabroad/netherlands" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">study abroad</a> website for the Netherlands.</p>
<p><span style="font-size: small;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="line-height: 28px;"><br />
</span></span></p>
</div>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<article id="post-4762" class="post-4762 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Tara Hottman receives Berlin Program Fellowship</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/tara-hottman-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="1:05 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-04-01T13:05:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 1, 2015</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/thottman/">Tara Hottman</a> will be in Berlin next year through a fellowship with the <a href="http://www.fu-berlin.de/en/sites/bprogram/" target="_blank">Berlin Program for Advanced German and European Studies</a> working on her project "The Past as Utopia: Alexander Kluge and the Archive".</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/uncategorized/" rel="category tag">Uncategorized</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/tara-hottman-receives-berlin-program-fellowship/" title="1:05 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2015-04-01T13:05:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">April 1, 2015</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/chench/" title="View all posts by Christopher Hench" rel="author" itemprop="url">Christopher Hench</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->

				<nav class="nav-single">
					<h3 class="assistive-text">Post navigation</h3>

		<div id="content" role="main">

			
				
	<article id="post-2757" class="post-2757 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
				<header class="entry-header">
						<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Two Undergraduate Majors Receive Scholarships</h1>
						<div class="entry-meta"><span class="by-author"><span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span> <span class="meta-separator">&bull;</span> <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/two-undergraduate-majors-receive-scholarships/" title="2:11 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-05-31T14:11:46+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2011</time></a>  
											</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
					</header><!-- .entry-header -->

				<div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">
			<p>Keighley McFarland and Katja Minitenko, two of our German Majors, received undergraduate merit scholarships from the Institute of International Studies and were accepted as members of the IIS Junior Scholars Program for Spring 2011.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
		
		<footer class="entry-meta">
			Posted in <span itemprop="articleSection"><a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/category/news/" rel="category tag">News</a></span> on <a href="http://german.berkeley.edu/two-undergraduate-majors-receive-scholarships/" title="2:11 pm" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date updated" datetime="2011-05-31T14:11:46+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">May 31, 2011</time></a><span class="by-author"> by <span class="author vcard" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a class="url fn n" href="http://german.berkeley.edu/author/ccj1/" title="View all posts by Courtney C Johnson" rel="author" itemprop="url">Courtney C Johnson</a></span></span></span>.						
		</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
	</article><!-- #post -->
